05.23.2008	One day after hurricane forecasters predicted a busy hurricane season, U.S. Representative and Florida Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) called on Floridians to take the necessary steps to prepare for this year's hurricane season. share: f t One day after hurricane forecasters predicted a busy hurricane season, U.S. Representative and Florida Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) called on Floridians to take the necessary steps to prepare for this year's hurricane season. Yesterday, the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration (NOAA) Climate Prediction Center's 2008 hurricane season outlook indicated that there could be a more than 60 % chance of up to 16 named storms, including up to 9 hurricanes and up to 5 major hurricanes. Hurricane season begins on June 1. "People throughout Florida are all too aware of the destruction and devastation hurricanes can cause. In light of the actively predicated hurricane season, the people of Florida should make sure they are properly prepared and have an emergency plan in place for their families," said Representative Hastings. "Sadly, the United States still lacks a comprehensive hurricane research program. Until that happens - and even beyond - people need to make it their own personal responsibility to prepare for future storms." In addition to calling on Floridians to prepare for hurricane season, Representative Hastings warned that the Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) planned closing of its Long-Term Recovery Office (FLTRO) could negatively impact the Federal government's ability to respond to any hurricane or other national disaster in Florida. The FLTRO was established in 2005 in response to the 2004 hurricanes and has since become a crucial underpinning of Florida's efforts to prepare and respond to disasters. For the past two years, the existence of the Office has saved countless funds and lives. The Office has been successful in expediting recovery efforts and public assistance reimbursements to state and local governments, while also providing significant mitigation funding and guidance to local governments working to reduce their risk from future storms. However, FEMA has started to downsize the office despite hurricane season being just around the corner. "Every day that the planned termination of the FEMA Long-Term Recovery Office continues, Florida loses an invaluable means to be able to prepare, respond and mitigate future hurricanes. Now, local governments and people throughout the State need to be that much more prepared in order to attempt to supplant the immense benefits the Office has brought to the State. FEMA needs to take the advice of the many leaders in Congress and throughout the State and make the office permanent," noted Rep. Hastings. In 2007, the U.S. House of Representatives adopted an amendment to the Homeland Security Authorization bill authored by Representative Hastings that would keep the office open for at least the next three years. The 2008 Omnibus Appropriations bill (P.L.110-161) mandated that the Florida Long-Term Recovery Office remain open until all casework dealing with the 2004 hurricanes is completed. Rep. Hastings has also introduced H.R. 2407, the National Hurricane Research Initiative Act of 2007, with a bipartisan group of Florida legislators. The bill calls for the implementation of a strategic action plan to improve the nation's hurricane research, prediction and preparation abilities. # # # #

05.09.2008	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) called on the South Florida flying public to attend the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) upcoming public meeting on Tuesday, May 13, 2008 at 7:00 PM at the Holiday Inn Palm Beach-Airport Conference Center in West Palm Beach regarding the fate of the Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) at Palm Beach International Airport (PBI). share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) called on the South Florida flying public to attend the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) upcoming public meeting on Tuesday, May 13, 2008 at 7:00 PM at the Holiday Inn Palm Beach-Airport Conference Center in West Palm Beach regarding the fate of the Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) at Palm Beach International Airport (PBI). The meeting was scheduled at Representative Hastings' request to follow-up on two previous meetings in January and April 2008. At those meetings, the FAA failed to answer the most basic questions regarding the FAA's consolidation plans, including concerns regarding safety, air traffic controller interoperability, the continuation of services, and continued communication between air traffic controllers and pilots - all areas which will be negatively impacted in South Florida if the FAA's TRACON consolidation plans are successful. "At the first meeting, the FAA staff failed to produce even one sheet of paper explaining how their proposal for consolidation would play out on the ground. At the second, the comments from some FAA officials made it clear to me that this decision was made without any due diligence," remarked Representative Hastings. "The FAA has missed great opportunities to meaningfully engage the public and seriously consider the needs of South Florida. It is absolutely necessary for the public to attend this renewed opportunity and share their concerns." After a FAA public meeting on January 14, 2008, Representative Hastings wrote a letter to the FAA expressing his discontent with the manner in which the meeting was facilitated. At another public meeting on April 10, 2008, Representative Hastings' staff pressured the FAA on issues regarding safety and planning for South Florida's airspace. During that meeting, senior FAA officials failed to provide adequate justification for consolidating the PBI TRACON. Representative Hastings has since met with FAA Acting Administrator Bobby Sturgell and remains deeply concerned that the FAA made a decision doing its due diligence. The TRACON system guides planes within a 50 mile radius of the airport on their final approaches. In an effort to save money, the FAA has embarked on an ambitious plan to consolidate dozens of TRACON systems throughout the country. Despite overwhelming opposition from air traffic controllers, local pilots, aircraft owners, the South Florida and Treasure Coast Congressional Delegations and local officials, the FAA is attempting to consolidate the TRACONs of all South Florida international airports into one at Miami International Airport (MIA). Representative Hastings has warned that under the FAA's plan, all South Florida airports - domestic and international - will be left without an approach radar system if a natural disaster or terrorist attack were to destroy the TRACON at MIA. The FAA's contingency plan would require that controllers in Jacksonville, an airport more than 350 miles away, direct approaching aircraft not only in their assigned region, but throughout all of South Florida and virtually the entire state without additional staff and technology. Representative Hastings has led the fight in Washington to block the FAA's consolidation plan. On three separate occasions since 2006, the House of Representatives has adopted legislative language authored by Representative Hastings blocking the FAA from consolidating the PBI TRACON, expressing Congressional opposition to the unnecessary consolidation of TRACONs in the interest of air system functionality, disaster response, and national security. This listening session will provide a public opportunity for comment on FAA's plans to eliminate the PBI TRACON. FAA Public Meeting on PBI TRACON Tuesday, May 13, 2008 - 7:00 PM Holiday Inn Palm Beach-Airport Conference Center 1301 Belvedere Road, West Palm Beach, FL

Bush The White House Washington, DC 20500 Dear Mr. President, We write to request that your Administration make emergency relief for Haiti a high priority. The most important and direct way to do this would be by dedicating no less than $60 million for Haiti when allocating the remaining fiscal year 2008 funding from the Title II Food for Peace Program and the resources made available by the recent drawdown of funds from the Bill Emerson Humanitarian Trust, an action announced by the Secretary of Agriculture on April 14, 2008. In early 2007, U.N. peacekeepers restored stability to the country by driving most gang activity out of Port-au-Prince's notorious slums, and the Haitian government began to forge ahead with a comprehensive plan for economic growth. Today, Haiti is facing another crisis that threatens to derail this progress. Earlier this month, riots protesting high food prices broke out in the southern city of Les Cayes and quickly spread throughout the country. The rising cost of food has placed additional hardship on Haiti's people, three-quarters of whom live on less than $2 a day. Additionally, 1 in 5 children is chronically malnourished and a recent New York Times story reported that one booming business is the selling of patties made of mud, oil and sugar typically eaten by the most destitute. To respond to this crisis, President Préval announced new measures that would reduce the price of a 50-Kilogram bag of rice from $51 to $43, or by 16%. In a country in Haiti's current condition, this reduction could mean the difference between eating and going hungry for many destitute families. The United States must now demonstrate leadership to resolve and help one of its closest neighbors. It is not in the United States' interest for Haiti to descend into turmoil. We strongly urge you to immediately provide these necessary funds and send Secretary Rice to Haiti to emphasize our commitment to our neighbor and ally. We commend your continued desire to help those suffering from humanitarian crisis around the world. We urge you now to come to the aid of the Haitian people who are suffering in our own backyard at this crucial time. Sincerely, Alcee L. Hastings Kendrick B. Meek Jo Ann Emerson James P. 04.30.2008	At a press conference held this morning in the U.S. Capitol, U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL) and several Members of the Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) called for immediate U.S. intervention to alleviate the humanitarian crisis in Haiti. share: f t At a press conference held this morning in the U.S. Capitol, U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL) and several Members of the Congressional Black Caucus (CBC) called for immediate U.S. intervention to alleviate the humanitarian crisis in Haiti. Representative Hastings and others asked President Bush to expedite debt relief to Haiti, increase food aid, and extend Temporary Protected Status (TPS) for Haitian immigrants currently in the United States. Last week, the 42 House Members of the CBC signed a letter authored by Representative Hastings to President Bush urging that him to increase effort to address Haiti's current economic and political instability and requesting a meeting with him to discuss the situation in Haiti. Despite countless attempts by Representative Hastings, the White House has yet to confirm a meeting with Members of the CBC. Representative Hastings released the following statement in conjunction with today's press conference: "As Members of the Congressional Black Caucus, we call on President Bush to immediately provide for the short-term relief of Haitians and for a long-term sustained development plan for Haiti by addressing three things. "First, we need to work together to expedite the cancellation of Haiti's debt to international institutions. Haiti is scheduled to pay approximately $50 million dollars in 2008 to multilateral financial institutions. Canceling Haiti's debt will help alleviate poverty and increase stability in Haiti. Just last week the House went on record of supporting expedited debt relief to Haiti. We have done our work, now the President must do his. "Second, the President must grant Haitian nationals Temporary Protected Status. The Coast Guard has already interdicted 972 Haitians in 2008, 247 this month alone. Just last week, more than 25 Haitians died off the coast of the Bahamas when their boat capsized. Stabilizing Haiti will stop the mass exodus to the United States coming from Haiti right now. "Haitians have long endured our nation's double-standard, immigration policies. Granting TPS is the most inexpensive and immediate form of aid the President can single-handedly provide. "Haiti has suffered from multiple natural disasters, political instability, and dire poverty and has met the conditions under which a nation may be granted TPS according to U.S. law. How desperate must the humanitarian crisis in Haiti become before the United States grants Haitians TPS status? "Finally, we must expand our humanitarian efforts and provide immediate and lasting food relief to Haiti. "The President's recent steps to alleviate the food crisis in Haiti fall far short of what is immediately required. Releasing a portion of $200 million in emergency food aid to Haiti and redirecting $6.5 million in existing aid funds to Haiti is a drop in the bucket when at this moment Haitians are crying out that their hunger pain feels like they are ‘eating Clorox.' Reports of Haitian children being forced to eat soap and mud cookies just to stay nourished are beyond troubling. "The 2008 Emergency Supplemental President Bush submitted to Congress only included $350 million in food assistance to needy countries. We must add to that amount and ensure that a significant amount of the $350 million is allocated to Haiti. "This issue is of significant importance to me and my colleagues in the Congressional Black Caucus. The powers that be must step up to the plate and do what is necessary to save the innocent before it is too late." Representative Hastings has long been a leader in issues relating to Haiti. This past month he authored an amendment to H.R. 2634, the Jubilee Act for Responsible Lending and Expanded Debt Cancellation, which unanimously passed the House of Representatives, calling for the immediate cancellation of Haiti's international debt. He is also the author of H.R. 522, the Haitian Protection Act, legislation which would designate Haitian nationals in the United States as eligible for Temporary Protected Status (TPS). Representative Hastings has been calling for the extension of TPS to Haitian nationals for years. # # # #

04.08.2008	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) announced today that at his request the Federal Aviation Administration will convene a second public meeting/listening session on Thursday, April 10, 2008 at 7:00 PM at the Hilton Palm Beach Airport in West Palm Beach to follow-up on a previous meeting in January 2008 on the fate of the Terminal Radar Approach Control at Palm Beach International Airport. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) announced today that at his request the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) will convene a second public meeting/listening session on Thursday, April 10, 2008 at 7:00 PM at the Hilton Palm Beach Airport in West Palm Beach to follow-up on a previous meeting in January 2008 on the fate of the Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) at Palm Beach International Airport (PBI). After a previous meeting on January 14, 2008, Representative Hastings wrote a letter to the FAA expressing his discontent with the manner in which the meeting was facilitated. "The FAA staff failed to produce even one sheet of paper explaining how their proposal for consolidation would play out on the ground," remarked Representative Hastings. "The FAA missed a great opportunity to meaningfully engage the public and seriously consider the needs of South Florida. It is absolutely necessary for the public to attend this renewed opportunity and share their concerns." The TRACON system guides planes within a 50 mile radius of the airport on their final approaches. In an effort to save money, the FAA has embarked on an ambitious plan to consolidate dozens of TRACON systems throughout the country. Despite overwhelming opposition from air traffic controllers, local pilots, aircraft owners, the South Florida and Treasure Coast Congressional Delegations and local officials, the FAA is attempting to consolidate the TRACONs of all South Florida international airports into one at Miami International Airport (MIA). Representative Hastings has warned that under the FAA's plan, all South Florida airports - domestic and international - will be left without an approach radar system if a natural disaster or terrorist attack were to destroy the TRACON at MIA. The FAA's contingency plan would require that controllers in Jacksonville, an airport more than 350 miles away, direct approaching aircraft not only in their assigned region, but throughout all of South Florida and virtually the entire state without additional staff and technology. "For the sake of imagined efficiency, the FAA is on the verge of jeopardizing the security and functionality of our airspace in South Florida," Hastings said. "It is absolutely necessary for the public to have a chance to say something about it." Representative Hastings has led the fight in Washington to block the FAA's consolidation plan. On three separate occasions since 2006, the House of Representatives has adopted legislative language authored by Representative Hastings blocking the FAA from consolidating the PBI TRACON, expressing Congressional opposition to the unnecessary consolidation of TRACONs in the interest of air system functionality, disaster response, and national security. This listening session will provide a public opportunity for comment on FAA's plans to eliminate the PBI TRACON. FAA Public Meeting on PBI TRACON Thursday, April 10, 2008 - 7:00 PM Hilton Palm Beach Airport Hotel 150 Australian Avenue, West Palm Beach, FL For more information about Representative Hastings' involvement in this issue over the years, visit /. ####
04.03.2008	U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Rush D. Holt (D-NJ), and Michael C. Burgess (R-TX) introduced bipartisan legislation today which will restore the federal-local partnership in covering medical expenses for incarcerated individuals before they are adjudicated. share: f t U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Rush D. Holt (D-NJ), and Michael C. Burgess (R-TX) introduced bipartisan legislation today which will restore the federal-local partnership in covering medical expenses for incarcerated individuals before they are adjudicated. The Restoring the Partnership for County Health Care Costs Act of 2008 ensures that individuals currently receiving Medicaid, Medicare, or Social Security Insurance (SSI) will continue to receive those benefits until they are tried and convicted and that local governments will not be forced to cover the medical expenses of individuals who have not yet been convicted of any wrong doing."The Federal and local governments are partners in ensuring that all of our residents have medical coverage. Neither partner should be bearing an unfair burden in meeting this mandate," said Representative Hastings. "Stripping people of their federal benefits before that have been convicted of anything is a direct contradiction of the basic presumption of innocence which is the foundation of the American criminal justice system. And for the federal government to stick local governments with the tab for this contradictory policy is just plain wrong." "This is a simple matter of fairness," said Representative Holt. "The federal government should not saddle states and counties - who are already facing difficult fiscal challenges - with these costs. Our bill would correct this historic unfairness." "Cost-shifting, whether public or private, undermines efforts to control the growing costs of health care," said Representative Burgess. "This bill targets the cost-shifting between different levels of government to keep costs in check and keep people covered." A person incarcerated in a county jail or juvenile detention facility in almost all states is ineligible to receive Medicare, Medicaid, of SSI benefits once they enter the facility. Under current law, however, the suspension of benefits occurs prior to the issuance of formal charges or conviction. As a result, local governments (usually county governments) are responsible for not only meeting and paying for the mandate that all individuals who are inmates of public institutions be provided with health care, but also for the days, weeks, months, and even years leading up to an actual conviction. If a person is found innocent, the reinstatement of federal benefits - benefits which should not have been taken away in the first place - can takes months while the local government continues to be responsible for covering the non-reimbursable costs associated with providing the federally-mandated health care to these individuals. The bipartisan Restoring the Partnership for County Health Care Costs Act of 2008 addresses this issue by prohibiting the federal government from stripping individuals of their Medicare, Medicaid, and SSI benefits prior to actually being convicted. Critically, it reaffirms the federal-local partnership in meeting this mandate. The bill enjoys the support of the National Association of Counties. "This is a costly problem for counties because county governments are responsible for all inmate health care costs," said Larry E. Naake, executive director, National Association of Counties. "Counties accept that responsibility. But it is unreasonable that federal eligibility should be cut off arbitrarily - even before a person has been tried and convicted or acquitted - shifting all their healthcare costs to local taxpayers. We strongly urge Congress to promptly pass this bill and send it to the president's desk for his signature."
02.28.2008	U.S. Representative and Florida Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued the following statement on today's announced resignation of Scott Morris, Director of Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Florida Long-Term Recovery Office. share: f t U.S. Representative and Florida Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued the following statement on today's announced resignation of Scott Morris, Director of Federal Emergency Management Agency's (FEMA) Florida Long-Term Recovery Office. "I wish to express my deep gratitude and appreciation for Mr. Morris' leadership and commitment to helping Florida's communities recover from past disasters and prepare for those in the future. His service has been an asset to my constituents and to the entire state of Florida during these trying times, and I wish him the best of luck in all of his future endeavors. "The work of this office in the last three years to help Florida's communities prepare for, respond to, and mitigate the hurricanes and storms that constantly threaten our state has been so critically important. The tremendous safety and economic value that the office provides to our state and so many others reinforces the urgent need for it to be permanently established. The office must also be relevant and active in all present and future disasters. In doing so, FEMA will save taxpayer dollars and lives. The safety and well-being of our communities depend on it." Florida's Long-Term Recovery Office has become a vital component of Florida's and the entire Southeast Region's efforts to cope with hurricanes and tropical storms. Since 2005, the full-time recovery staff has more than tripled the daily reimbursement rate, sent out more mitigation funds to recipients than ever before in FEMA's history, and created the first and only Fraud Prevention Unit within FEMA. The office has also closed down two large scale housing missions - something never accomplished in all of FEMA's history. Today, many of the office's successful techniques first tried in Florida are now being employed throughout the Gulf Coast with equal success. On May 9, 2007, the House of Representatives unanimously adopted an amendment to the Homeland Security Authorization bill authored by Representative Hastings that would keep the office open for at least the next three years. The 2008 Omnibus Appropriations bill (P.L.110-161) included language mandating that the Florida Long-Term Recovery Office remain open until all casework dealing with the 2004 hurricanes is completed and directed FEMA to notify the Committees on Appropriations prior to closing the office. # # # #

02.04.2008	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today reacted to President Bush's Fiscal Year (FY) 2009 budget request which reflects a continuation of the President's seven years of misguided fiscal policy which squandered a $5.6 trillion 10-year surplus and replaced it with a $3.2 trillion deficit share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today reacted to President Bush's Fiscal Year (FY) 2009 budget request which reflects a continuation of the President's seven years of misguided fiscal policy which squandered a $5.6 trillion 10-year surplus and replaced it with a $3.2 trillion deficit. In his request to Congress, the President's budget proposes a deficit of over $400 million in 2009 alone - the second largest in the history of the country. The five biggest deficits in American history have all occurred during President Bush's time in office (2003, 2004, 2005, 2008, and 2009). "The most promising thing about this budget is that it's this President's last," said Representative Hastings. "President Bush and the previous Republican majorities in Congress have mortgaged the future of our country on the backs of our children and grandchildren. They cut and cut and cut the most vital programs our government offers to those most in need while driving our economy into the ground by funding a needless war for oil. The Bush economic record is one of absolute failure which will require years of repair." Some of the largest funding cuts in the Bush Budget include: - $556 billion in Medicare cuts over the next ten years; - $570 million in cuts in 2009 alone for the Low-Income Home Energy Program (LIHEAP), a program which helps low-income Americans pay their energy bills; - Elimination of the Community Oriented Policing Services (COPS) program, a program which has put literally hundreds of police officers on the streets of South Florida; - $500 million in cuts in 2009 to the Social Services Block Grant (SSBG) program and the complete elimination of the program in 2010; - $330 million in cuts in 2009 from the Environmental Protection Agency's (EPA) budget; - A 35% cut in Environmental Justice programs; and - $5.2 billion in new fees on veterans over the next 10 years. In the state of Florida, the President's budget request also grossly underfunds Everglades restoration and the rehabilitation of the Herbert Hoover Dike. The President's budget includes $77.8 million for the rehabilitation of the Herbert Hoover Dike, nearly 50 percent less in funding than is needed in 2009 to expedite the repairs of the Dike. Further, the President's proposed $215 million for all Everglades restoration efforts is approximately $156 million short of the funding the Everglades actually needs. Finally, the President only included $4.5 million for the design work of the Indian River Lagoon restoration project while budgeting nothing for the actual construction of the Lagoon, a move that will result in further delays to the completion of the Lagoon and other critical restoration projects. "It is simply unacceptable that President Bush is refusing to fully fund expedited repairs of the Herbert Hoover Dike. This is one of the five most vulnerable United States coastal spots, and it could not be more obvious that the President could not care less about accelerating repairs and truly securing our nation's most vulnerable communities," Representative Hastings noted. "President Bush's failure to fund two of the three most critical Everglades restoration project furthers his legacy as a President who has failed to live up to his campaign commitment to clean up the Everglades. It is now up to Democrats in Congress - and likely a Democratic President - to clean up this mess and ensure that Everglades restoration is not further delayed by this President's negligence." # # # #

Hastings (D-Miramar) announced today that he is encouraged by recent work done by the Army Corps of Engineers to initiate construction on a test panel for a cutoff wall and to increase expert reviews and consultation as part of efforts to repair the Herbert Hoover Dike. The Dike, which is in desperate need of rehabilitation, was built in the 1930s to protect those living in the communities along the shores of Lake Okeechobee. Representative Hastings secured almost $55 million in the Fiscal Year 2008 Omnibus Appropriations bill to expedite repairs to the Dike. "In order to guarantee the safety and security of my constituents who reside near and around Lake Okeechobee, we need to ensure appropriate and swift rehabilitation of the Dike," said Representative Hastings. "I appreciate the recent progress made by the Army Corps of Engineers to repair the Dike. The innovative engineering technology work on this project is an important step forward in ongoing efforts to stabilize the Dike. I am encouraged by the recent advancements made on a long, stagnant problem, and I pledge to continue to engage our Lake Region communities and push the Army Corps of Engineers to guarantee that the Dike is stabilized as expeditiously and safely as possible." Since the deadly hurricanes of 1928, governments at all levels have joined together to maintain safe levels for Lake Okeechobee and repair the Herbert Hoover Dike to prevent its possible failure. Representative Hastings has been working since 2005 with officials at all levels of government to develop and implement a comprehensive plan to rehabilitate the Dike and prevent any possible flooding of the surrounding communities. On January 19, 2008, the Army Corps of Engineers announced that contractors began construction of a test panel for a cutoff wall in Port Mayaca as part of the rehabilitation of the Herbert Hoover Dike. # # # #

12.20.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and a coalition of 24 colleagues today reintroduced legislation to require that federal agencies establish and integrate environmental justice programs into their everyday activities. The Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act of 2007 establishes offices of environmental justice in almost two dozen federal departments and agencies, promotes agency integration of environmental justice objectives, and increases public access to information about environmental hazards. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and a coalition of 24 colleagues today reintroduced legislation to require that federal agencies establish and integrate environmental justice programs into their everyday activities. The Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act of 2007 establishes offices of environmental justice in almost two dozen federal departments and agencies, promotes agency integration of environmental justice objectives, and increases public access to information about environmental hazards. "This legislation will require federal agencies to put their money where there mouth is to meet the expectations of Executive Order 12898," remarked Representative Hastings. "Our communities deserve access to information about the hazards of their immediate environment and have waited well over a decade for the goals set forth by the Executive Order to be met." Executive Order 12898, Federal Actions to Address Environmental Justice in Minority Populations and Low-Income Populations, was signed by former President Clinton on February 11, 1994. This policy statement requires that all appropriate federal agencies collect data on the health and environmental impact of their programs and activities on minority populations and low-income populations and to develop policies to ensure that minority and underserved communities are not adversely impacted by poor environmental, energy, and health policy decisions. Specifically, the Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act: Establishes Offices of Environmental Justice in agencies which make and implement policy that could disproportionately impact underserved communities; Integrates environmental justice commitments into the core missions of relevant federal agencies; Formally establishes the Interagency Working Group on Environmental Justice and increase its role in ensuring the environmental and health protection of all communities; Formalizes public participation in federal environmental justice initiatives; and Establishes Community Technology Centers to increase public access to information about environmental toxins and contaminants in their communities. Additionally, several important updates to this legislation include: Authorization of specific funding for the establishment of an "Office of Environmental Justice" in each of an expanded group of relevant federal agencies; Refinements to the criteria for the establishment of "Community Technology Centers," to increase accessibility; and Additions of reporting requirements to increase the effectiveness of federal agency implementation and ensure proper Congressional oversight. "For over a decade, agencies have been mandated to examine the impact of their policies on the environmental health of minority and low-income communities. Once we give those mandates true legal standing, we can then turn them into action that directly serves our communities." Representative Hastings added, "Congress must require accountability and conscience in our federal permitting processes and environmental action to reduce the burden on low-income populations and communities of color. The provisions of the Environmental Justice Access and Implementation Act will do just that." ####
12.12.2007	U.S. Representative Hastings today applauded the historic decision of the U.S. Supreme Court and the United States Sentencing Commission to reform the two decade-long discriminatory crack and powder cocaine sentencing guidelines. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today applauded the historic decision of the U.S. Supreme Court and the United States Sentencing Commission to reform the two decade-long discriminatory crack and powder cocaine sentencing guidelines that required 100 times more powder cocaine to warrant the same mandatory minimum prison sentence as crack. "I applaud the landmark Supreme Court ruling and the United States Sentencing Commission's decision to address the disparity between crack and powder cocaine sentencing laws and applying crack sentencing guidelines retroactively," said Representative Hastings. "In the midst of the ‘War on Drugs,' these draconian sentencing guidelines were justified though the false belief that crack and its users posed a greater threat to our society than powder cocaine. Rather than waging war on drugs, this policy waged war on America's poor and minorities. Hundreds of thousands of men and women, the overwhelming number of whom are black, have been convicted through a federal statute that was rooted in propaganda rather than empirical data." In the mid-1980's, crack cocaine became prevalent and was portrayed as a violence-inducing, highly addictive plague of the poor in inner cities. In truth, crack and powder cocaine are chemically similar, with the primary difference between crack and powder cocaine being the cost. Despite this fact, the notoriety surrounding crack led to the passage of a federal sentencing law in 1986 that required 100 times more powder cocaine to elicit the same mandatory minimum sentence as crack. On Monday of this week, the U.S. Supreme Court ruled that federal judges have the discretion to give "reasonably" shorter prison terms for crack cocaine crimes to reduce the disparity with crimes involving cocaine powder. Yesterday, the United States Sentencing Commission voted to apply less harsh crack sentencing guidelines retroactively to individuals who were convicted under the old sentencing policy. "This policy perpetuated the destruction of our communities rather than growth and development. It favored imprisonment, not rehabilitation. Now, more than twenty years after the implementation of this drug policy, our prisons, economy and communities are feeling the strain," Representative Hastings said. "As an attorney, former judge, and now Congressman, I have worked tirelessly to ensure that our nation's criminal justice system is truly just. After years of countless attempts to correct this statute on drug criminalization and sentencing, the country has at last taken a crucial first step in the right direction." Representative Hastings is a co-sponsor of H.R. 460, the Crack-Cocaine Equitable Sentencing Act of 2007 and H.R. 2456, the Crack-Cocaine Equitable Sentencing Act of 2005. # # # #
12.11.2007	The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously passed a resolution honoring Barrington Irving, the youngest pilot and first person of African descent to ever fly solo around the world (H. Res. 661). The resolution was introduced by U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Kendrick B. Meek (D-Miami). share: f t The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously passed a resolution honoring Barrington Irving, the youngest pilot and first person of African descent to ever fly solo around the world (H. Res. 661). The resolution was introduced by U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Kendrick B. Meek (D-Miami), and encourages the pursuit of more initiatives like Irving's nonprofit organization, Experience Aviation, Inc., which encourages youth and underrepresented groups to pursue careers in aviation. "Barrington Irving is one of the greatest young heroes of our time," remarked Representative Hastings. "His triumph demonstrates that if you reach for the sky, you truly can make it, and in turn, make history. The passage of this resolution is one of many initiatives to come that will reprioritize opportunities in aviation for our youth." "When the younger generation is looking for a role model and hero, they need to look no further than Barrington Irving," said Reprsentative Meek. "This young pilot proved that when you dream big dreams and work hard, the extraordinary is possible. I am honored to call Barrington Irving a constituent." Irving departed from Opa Locka Executive Airport in Opa Locka, Florida on March 23, 2007 and returned on June 27, 2007. His 24,600 mile flight took him to 27 cities around the world where he met with youth as an ambassador of opportunities in aviation. Representatives Hastings and Meek introduced H. Res. 661 with 9 other original cosponsors. The bill passed with 44 bi-partisan cosponsors. ####
12.07.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today encouraged his constituents to acquire the 50th anniversary of the desegregation of Little Rock Central High School commemorative coin before they are no longer available. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today encouraged his constituents to acquire the 50th anniversary of the desegregation of Little Rock Central High School commemorative coin before they are no longer available. The United States Mint has issued 500,000 silver dollar coins to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the desegregation of Little Rock Central High School. The last day to order the significant coin from the U.S. Mint is next Friday, December 14, 2007. Those who are interested can order the coin either at www.usmint.gov or by calling 1-800-USA-MINT (872-6468). "As one entrenched in the effort to desegregate schools in South Florida, I applaud this tribute to the implementation of Brown v. Board of Education," said Representative Hastings. "The integration of Little Rock Central High School was a monumental triumph worthy of a commemorative coin, and I encourage all to seize the opportunity to own this invaluable piece of history." Commemorative coins are authorized by Congress and issued by the U.S. Mint in limited quantities for a limited time. These silver dollars celebrate and honor American people, places, events, and institutions. Under current law, the U.S. Mint produces only two sets of commemorative coins each year. The commemorative coins for 2007 are the Little Rock Central High School Desegregation Coin and the Jamestown 400th Anniversary Coin. The 2007 Little Rock Central High School Desegregation 50th Anniversary Commemorative Coin honors the desegregation of Little Rock Central High School by featuring the high school as it looked in 1957 and the hopeful footsteps of the nine students under the protection of the 101st Airborne Division. In 1957, Little Rock Central High School was the site of the first major national test for the implementation of the U.S. Supreme Court's Brown v. Board of Education of Topeka decision. Its desegregation by nine courageous teenagers, known as the "Little Rock Nine," became a prominent example of equality under the rule of law setting the foundation to allow access for African American students to receive the education that they deserved. In tribute to the advancements made toward achieving equality for all Americans to date, Congress directed the production of these unique silver dollar coins. $10 from the sale of each coin will be directed toward preserving the history of the Little Rock Central High School National Historic Site and share the story of the Little Rock Nine with today's young citizens. The coin represents a unique opportunity for all Americans to partake in the educational effort to teach all Americans about the historical impact of this historic event and their ability to continue making positive change in the world. Representative Hastings was a cosponsor of the original resolution which led to the minting of the Little Rock Central High School Desegregation Commemorative Coin. # # # #
12.05.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued the following statement in response to Northern Federal District of Florida Judge Robert Hinkle's ruling this afternoon that the Democratic National Committee (DNC) is not acting illegally in stripping Florida Democrats of their right to have their vote count in the 2008 Presidential Primary Election: share: f t Honoring the 60th anniversary of the Everglades National Park, U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Mario Diaz- Balart (R-Miami) today introduced important bipartisan legislation recognizing the anniversary and dedicating Congress to restoration efforts of this pristine ecosystem. Representatives Hastings and Diaz-Balart are the bipartisan Co-Chairs of the House Everglades Caucus. "Restoring the Everglades remains neither a Democratic nor a Republican issue, but a Florida issue. Our legislation highlights the importance that Florida Members of Congress place on preserving and protecting the Rivers of Grass for all future generations of Americans to enjoy. We led the fight to override the President's veto and pass WRDA, and we will continue our efforts to see this restoration through," said Representative Hastings. "Representative Diaz-Balart and I have been working together to preserve the Everglades for years, and I am pleased to be introducing this resolution with him." "It is a great honor to be the sole Member of Congress representing the entire Everglades National Park. Creating awareness about the importance of the Everglades has always been a priority of mine and this resolution reaffirms Congress' commitment to the preservation and restoration of this natural treasure," said Congressman Diaz-Balart. "I thank Congressman Hastings for joining me in this bipartisan effort and for always being a leader in recognizing the importance of the Florida Everglades." In 2000, the Federal government and the State of Florida embarked on the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP), the largest environmental restoration effort in history to repair and revive the ecosystem. Just last month, Congress overrode a President Bush veto and passed the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007, authorizing $1.8 billion in Everglades restoration funding and reaffirming Congressional support for Everglades Restoration. Original bipartisan cosponsors of the resolution included Representatives Lincoln Diaz-Balart, Allen Boyd, Corrine Brown, Vern Buchanan, Kathy Castor, Ric Keller, Ron Klein, Connie Mack, Tim Mahoney, Kendrick Meek, John Mica, Adam Putnam, Ileana Ros-Lehtinen, Debbie Wasserman Schultz and Robert Wexler. Florida Senators Bill Nelson and Mel Martinez are planning to introduce companion legislation in the Senate. A copy of the resolution is attached to this release. # # # #

11.14.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today applauded the announcement of the signing of a gaming compact between the Seminole Tribe of Florida and the State of Florida. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today applauded the announcement of the signing of a gaming compact between the Seminole Tribe of Florida and the State of Florida. The Compact will allow the Tribe to operate Class III slot machines and banked table card games at its seven existing facilities on tribal lands, including three in Broward County. "This Compact reaffirms the Seminole's sole authority to determine what happens on their land. It also ensures that that the State, too, will benefit from this historic agreement. It is my sincere hope that Governor Crist and the State Legislature will use the added revenue to fund the priorities of our state, including healthcare, education, and infrastructure," said Representative Hastings. "I applaud the Tribe and Governor Crist for their hard work in signing this Compact. I know that it was not easy and appreciate the time and effort on both sides to reach a final solution." Representative Hastings was an early supporter of the Compact and has been a lifetime supporter of the Seminole's inherent right to self-determination. He has been encouraging Governor Crist for months to do everything in his power to reach an agreement with the Seminoles before the U.S. Bureau of Indian Affairs approved the Seminole's Class III gaming application, essentially blocking the State from benefiting from the new gaming rules. # # # #
11.06.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued a statement today following the House of Representatives' overwhelming vote of 361-54 to override President Bush's veto of the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 2007 share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued the following statement today following the House of Representatives' overwhelming vote of 361-54 to override President Bush's veto of the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 2007: "This is a huge win for Florida and an even bigger win for the people of my district. This WRDA is long overdue, and I am euphoric that my House colleagues voted with me to override President Bush's short-sighted and ideologically-driven veto. This overwhelming House vote reaffirms that the President's misplaced priorities are as polluted as the water this bill will clean up. From restoring the Everglades to building the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in the Glades, finally, we can adequately address the vital water resource needs in my district and throughout Florida." Among other significant projects, WRDA 2007 includes federal funding authorizations of $7.5 million for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in Palm Beach County and $1.8 billion to restore the Everglades, including $1.365 billion for the clean-up of the Indian River Lagoon, $375 million for the Picayune Strand, and $80.8 million for the Site 1 impoundment project in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade Counties. The Senate is scheduled to vote on overriding the President WRDA veto later this week. # # # #
11.02.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued a statement today blasting President Bush's veto of the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) issued the following statement today blasting President Bush's veto of the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007 today: "This veto proves once again how out of step this President is with the priorities of this country. Not only has he refused to give health insurance to 10 million children, but now President Bush is denying clean and safe drinking water to the American people. "The polluted mindset of this Administration is a clear indication that they do not understand the dynamics of pollution in American society and certainly not in my district. I invite the President to drink the water in Western Palm Beach County and smell the water in the Indian River Lagoon. Maybe then he'll realize what he's done to my constituents today. Sadly, I doubt it." Among other significant projects, WRDA 2007 includes federal funding authorizations of $7.5 million for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in Palm Beach County and $1.8 billion to restore the Everglades, including $1.365 billion for the clean-up of the Indian River Lagoon, $375 million for the Picayune Strand, and $80.8 million for the Site 1 impoundment project in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade Counties. Below is a detailed list of South Florida projects vetoed today by President Bush. # # # # U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings' Priorities in WRDA 2007 1. Lake Region Water Treatment Plan, Palm Beach County, (P. 570) The WRDA Conference Report authorizes $7.5 million for funding for the construction of the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant being built to serve Belle Glade, Pahokee and South Bay. 2. Indian River Lagoon (PP. 17-19) The WRDA Conference Report authorizes $1.365 billion for restoration of the Indian River Lagoon South. The project provides for ecosystem restoration, water supply, flood damage reduction, and protection of water quality. 3. Picayune Strand (P. 19) The WRDA Conference Report authorizes $375 million for environmental restoration of Picayune Strand. The Picayune Strand Ecosystem Restoration Plan would help increase freshwater flows to natural areas. 4. Site 1 Impoundment (PP. 19-20): The WRDA Conference Report authorizes $80.8 million for the environmental restoration of Site 1 Impoundment. The project consists of an aboveground reservoir. An inflow pump station will move water into the preserve from the Hillsboro Canal. Additional project components include a seepage control; system and remote-controlled gated culverts. The project is located in Palm Beach, Broward, and Miami-Dade Counties. 6. Hillsboro and Okeechobee Aquifer (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report includes modifying authorization for the Hillsboro and Lake Okeechobee Aquifer Project to increase the authorized project cost authorized in WRDA 1999 to $42.5 million. 7. Pilot Projects (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report amends the Water Resources Development Act of 2000 by authorizing a cost increase of the pilot projects from $69 million to $71.2 million, $34.5 million to $35.6 million, $6 million to $8.2 million and $3 million to $4.1 million. 8. Maximum Costs (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report authorizes a "Maximum cost of Program Authority" program. This provision authorizes the Secretary of the Army to apply the cost growth limits described by Section 902 of WRDA 1986 to the $25 million per project cap and the $206 million aggregate cost cap for Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan projects authorized under subsection 601(c) of WRDA 2000. 9. Credit (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report includes authorization of credit for construction completed by a non-federal sponsor prior to signing a project cooperation agreement under the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP). 10. Outreach and Assistance (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report applies Section 902 Growth Limit to the Additional Program. The Secretary may expend up to $3 million per fiscal year for fiscal years beginning after September 30, 2004 to for the Additional Program. 11. Critical Restoration Projects (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report includes language to increase Federal Funding caps for the Critical Restoration Projects that were authorized in WRDA 1996 from $75 million to $95 million and from $25 million to $30 million, to accommodate cost increases from inflation and minor design modifications since the WRDA 1996 authorization date. 12. Regional Engineering Model for Environmental Restoration (P. 723) The WRDA Conference Report includes authorization of $10 million to conduct a Regional Engineering Model for Environmental Restoration. The language requires the Secretary to complete the development and testing of the regional engineering model for environmental restoration as expeditiously as practicable. The model should be used for environmental restoration in the development of future water resource projects, including projects developed pursuant to section 601 of the Water Resources Development Act of 2000.
11.01.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced a resolution supporting increased Federal and State support for home and community-based services to the elderly and individuals with disabilities of any age. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced a resolution supporting increased Federal and State support for home and community-based services to the elderly and individuals with disabilities of any age. This resolution is being introduced on the first day of National Home Care and Hospice Month. "This legislation highlights the overall cost-effectiveness and improved outcomes in quality care for the elderly and disabled who are furnished health care in their homes or other community settings," said Representative Hastings when introducing the resolution today. "Increasing financial assistance and access to home and community-based services ensures that the quality of care individuals receive in their home and community is just as accessible an option as hospital and institutional attention." Representative Hastings' resolution supports studies which show that individuals who receive home and community-based care have greater life expectancies than those who are moved from everything that is familiar to them and placed in hospitals and other forms of institutional care. A need exists, however, for more training of professionals who will be capable of providing this care. "I wish to extend our sincere appreciation to Representative Alcee L. Hastings and his staff for introducing this important House Resolution which expresses aptly the need for increasing Federal and State support for home and community-based services for elderly and disabled individuals," said Val J. Halamandaris, President of the National Association for Home Care & Hospice. "The projected growth in the need for home care is being driven by demographics and our Nation does not have anywhere near the number of people needed to provide home care services. This is the last great civil rights battle and the least we can do is ensure that the infirm, disabled and dying Americans have the right to be cared for in their homes. I applaud Congressman Hastings for his interest in addressing this challenge." "Through adoption of uniformly high standards and increased training, we can ensure our citizens in need have access to qualified professionals when selecting home and community-based care," concluded Representative Hastings. ****

Hastings (D-Miramar) applauded the U.S. House of Representatives today for passing a bill designating the U.S. Federal Courthouse in Miami after former Chief Judge of the U.S. District Court of Southern Florida C. 10.24.2007	U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar), Kendrick B. Meek (D-Miami), and Corrine Brown (D-Jacksonville) have called for federal investigations into the acquittal of seven juvenile justice boot camp guards responsible for the death of Martin Lee Anderson in Bay County, Florida. share: f t U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar), Kendrick B. Meek (D-Miami), and Corrine Brown (D-Jacksonville) have called for federal investigations into the acquittal of seven juvenile justice boot camp guards responsible for the death of Martin Lee Anderson in Bay County, Florida and the treatment of juveniles at juvenile justice boot camps in Florida and throughout the nation. In letters sent to the U.S. Department of Justice and the House Judiciary Committee, Florida's three black U.S. Representatives called for an end to the negligent treatment and violent punishment of at risk youth in juvenile detention facilities. "Significant evidence suggests that discriminatory treatment has frequently occurred at juvenile boot camps. The unfortunate consequence of such treatment has not only been the death of Anderson, but also others in recent years," wrote the Representatives. "The negligence, violent punishment, and disciplinary procedures that many youths within these camps endure reflect a defunct paradigm that by no means rehabilitates at-risk youth, nor serves the intended purposes of the juvenile justice system." Representatives Hastings, Meek, and Brown are currently working with the House Judiciary Committee to convene a hearing to investigate the management of juvenile justice boot camps in Florida and the rest of the country. A copy of the letter to the U.S. Department of Justice follows. --- October 16, 2007 The Honorable Peter D. Keiser Acting Attorney General United States Department of Justice 950 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW Washington, DC 20530 Dear Attorney General Keiser: We write to ask that you investigate the persistent problems in the juvenile justice system and treatment at juvenile boot camps in Florida and throughout the country. As you may know, seven guards were recently acquitted in the October 12, 2007 verdict of the Martin Lee Anderson case in Bay County, Florida. This outcome has prompted us to contact you with our deep concerns. Press reports indicate that the Department of Justice will conduct an investigation of Anderson's death and other possible civil rights violations associated with the administration juvenile boot camps. We support action on this specific case and ask for this investigation to consider the excessive use of force and criminal negligence that persist throughout other juvenile boot camps in our state and throughout the country. According to testimony taken during the case as well as countless press accounts, significant evidence suggests that discriminatory treatment has frequently occurred at juvenile boot camps. The unfortunate consequence of such treatment has not only been death of Anderson, but also others in recent years, including Omar Paisley. Paisley was denied treatment for a burst appendix in a Miami-Dade County juvenile boot camp and those responsible for failing to act were never held accountable. The negligence, violent punishment, and disciplinary procedures that many youths within these camps endure reflects a defunct paradigm that by no means rehabilitates at-risk youth, nor serves the intended purposes of the juvenile justice system. Thus, any investigation into these cases should thoroughly evaluate the merit and effectiveness of boot camps in rehabilitating youth offenders. A serious investigation of this case will illuminate the injustices and discriminatory administration that pervade our juvenile justice system. Thank you for your consideration of our request. We look forward to your expeditious response. Sincerely, Alcee L. Hastings Member of Congress Corrine Brown Member of Congress Kendrick B. Meek Member of Congress # # # #
10.17.2007	Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (U.S. Helsinki Commission) and Congressman John Tanner (D-TN), Chairman of the House Delegation to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, sent a letter to House leadership, urging them to not bring the Armenian Genocide Resolution (H.Res. 106) to the floor for a vote. share: f t Send Letter to Pelosi and Hoyer Citing a Critical Time for U.S.-Turkish Relations, Troops Serving in the Region, and Stability in the Middle East Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (U.S. Helsinki Commission) and Congressman John Tanner (D-TN), Chairman of the House Delegation to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly, sent the following letter to Speaker of the House Nancy Pelosi (D-CA) and House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-MD), urging them to not bring the Armenian Genocide Resolution (H.Res.106) to the floor for a vote. On Wednesday, October 17, Hastings and Tanner, along with Representatives John Murtha (D-PA), Robert Wexler (D-FL), and Stephen Cohen (D-TN), will hold a press conference at 11:30 a.m. in H-321 of the Capitol, where they will urge House Leadership to reconsider its decision to bring H.Res.106 to the floor for a vote. (Please find below a copy of the letter) --- October 16, 2007 The Honorable Speaker Nancy Pelosi The Honorable Majority Leader Steny H. Hoyer United States House of Representatives Washington, D.C. 20515 Dear Speaker Pelosi and Majority Leader Hoyer: We write to express our concern regarding H. Res. 106, the Affirmation of the United States Record on the Armenian Genocide Resolution. By doing so, we in no way diminish the suffering and tragedy of the Armenian people under the Ottoman Empire, whose memory burns in the hearts and minds of their descendants. Enactment of H. Res. 106, which is directed at actions of the Ottoman Empire, would have serious consequences for the United States' important relationship with modern-day Turkey, a strong NATO ally; and threaten our operations and our troops serving in Iraq and Afghanistan. Turkey, a majority Muslim country, is a secular democracy geographically straddling the bridge between East and West at a time of turmoil and uncertainty for the countries in the region. In addition to being our partner in democracy, Turkey is also a key strategic ally. More than half of the cargo flown into Iraq and Afghanistan comes through Incirlik Air Base and this base would be a key component of any plans for redeployment of our troops in the future. In the wake of passage of H. Res. 106 by the Committee on Foreign Affairs, the Turkish government has recalled its Ambassador to the United States, Nabi Sensoy, to Ankara for consultations. In addition to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, eight former Secretaries of State and three Secretaries of Defense from the Clinton, Bush I, Reagan and Ford Administrations, have warned that passage of the resolution could imperil our national security interests as well as inhibit efforts toward reconciliation between Turkey and Armenia, including the possible opening of the border. Mesrob II, the spiritual leader of the Armenian Orthodox Community in Turkey has said, "The ‘Armenian Genocide Resolution' pending in the U.S. Congress disrupts both the relations between Turkish people and Armenians in Turkey and between Turkey and Armenia." We urge you to not bring the resolution before the House for a vote at this critical time for our men and women in uniform in the region, and for the stability of the Middle East. Sincerely, Chairman Alcee L. Hastings, M.C. Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe Chairman John S. Tanner, M.C. House Delegation to the NATO Parliamentary Assembly ####

"I laud the passage of this resolution by the House of Representatives; however the unfortunate fact is that this is long overdue. It is my hope that Mr. Ron Adam, who has been appointed chair of the U.N. Committee on Program and Coordination will help to normalize Israel's bilateral and multilateral relations with U.N. member states. The Commission consists of nine members from the United States Senate, nine from the House of Representatives, and one member each from the Departments of State, Defense and Commerce.
10.10.2007	The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously adopted an amendment to the National Affordable Housing Trust Fund Act (H.R. 2895) authored by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) requiring the Federal government to provide disaster and flood insurance counseling services to low- and middle-income families who receive assistance from the Affordable Housing Trust Fund created in the bill. share: f t The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously adopted an amendment to the National Affordable Housing Trust Fund Act (H.R. 2895) authored by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) requiring the Federal government to provide disaster and flood insurance counseling services to low- and middle-income families who receive assistance from the Affordable Housing Trust Fund created in the bill. "In many regions of our nation more prone to disasters, appropriate insurance is one of many added costs of homeownership that can push people to the edge," said Representative Hastings on the House floor today. "When you are on the edge, staying in your home or returning to your home after a disaster rests on having the right insurance." Under the National Affordable Housing Trust Fund Act, prior to receiving federal assistance from the Affordable Housing Trust Fund for purchasing a home, applicants are required to complete a counseling program on financial literacy, predatory lending, and foreclosure avoidance. Representative Hastings' amendment expands the counseling requirements to include disaster and flood insurance coverage. "We in South Florida and the Treasure Coast are still living the tragedies of withheld insurance during the 2004 and 2005 hurricanes - and so are the victims of Hurricane Katrina ," Representative Hastings noted. "Knowledge of the specifics and nuances in disaster and flood insurance policies will encourage further financial empowerment and homeownership stability among our nation's most vulnerable populations." In the first nine months of serving in the majority, House Democrats have worked to fulfill their commitment to increasing housing opportunities for working families. They have increased funding for public housing assistance and federal housing opportunities for seniors, as well as improving the Hope VI Grant Program. ####
10.10.2007	The U.S. House of Representatives passed bipartisan legislation today authored by U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Mark Kirk (R-IL) reauthorizing the Tropical Forest Conservation Act (TFCA) of 1998, an important "debt-for-nature" program which allows developing nations to reduce their foreign debt through investment in environmental protection programs. share: f t Officials at Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institution and Florida Aquarium Support Legislation. The U.S. House of Representatives passed bipartisan legislation today authored by U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Mark Kirk (R-IL) reauthorizing the Tropical Forest Conservation Act (TFCA) of 1998, an important "debt-for-nature" program which allows developing nations to reduce their foreign debt through investment in environmental protection programs. The bill (H.R. 2185) also expands the TFCA to include the preservation of coral reefs and marine habitats as eligible activities for debt relief and makes resources available for environmental stewardship that would otherwise be of the lowest priority in a developing country. "For the past seven years, the Tropical Forest Conservation Act has simultaneously provided debt relief for developing countries while promoting increased international tropical forest conservation. The reauthorization and expansion of this legislation will further ongoing conservation efforts and expand conservation to additional endangered marine environments while providing debt relief to previously excluded countries such as Chile, Jordan, Egypt, and Poland," Representative Hastings said. "Florida has been at the forefront of protecting endangered forests and coral reefs, constantly inventing strategies to rehabilitate these fragile marine habitats. This bill is truly a win-win-win for Florida, the United States, developing nations, and the entire planet." The legislation credits qualified developing nations for each dollar spent on a comprehensive tropical forest, coral reef or coastal habitat preservation or management programs. It also reduces debt by investing locally in programs which strengthen indigenous economies by creating long-term management policies that will preserve the natural resources upon which local commerce is based. To date, 11 nations have received debt credits under the Tropical Forest Conservation Act: Bangladesh, Belize, Botswana, Columbia, El Salvador, Guatemala, Jamaica, Panama, Paraguay, Peru and the Philippines. Dr. Brian Lapointe, Senior Research Scientist of the Harbor Branch Oceanographic Institution in Fort Pierce, Florida, strongly supported the reauthorization and expansion of the TCFA to include coral reefs and marine habitats. "Too many coral reefs are already permanently damaged. So few healthy reefs remain that those who are just old enough to start diving now will never know what a live and vibrant coral reef system should look like. It is imperative that restoration efforts be initiated right away," Dr. Lapointe said today. "Without this bill, more reefs will get extinguished and fewer people will experience the kaleidoscope of colors, light and life that make coral reefs one of our world's natural wonders. Congressman Hastings has a long and unwavering track record of speaking up for those who cannot do so for themselves. On behalf of Harbor Branch and the millions of children who otherwise will only see healthy reefs in pictures and movies, we thank Congressman Hastings for championing such an urgent cause." Thom Stork, Executive Director of the Florida Aquarium in Tampa, Florida, also expressed his support for the legislation. "The Florida Aquarium is excited and grateful for Congressman Hastings and Congressman Kirk's wisdom and foresight in including coral reefs in the TFCA reauthorization," said Mr. Stork. "Further, we are eager to bring our coral preservation expertise and unique coral health protocols to the table for each and every coral conservation/debt for nature initiative." The Tropical Forest and Coral Conservation Act is supported by The Nature Conservancy, Conservation International, World Wildlife Fund and Wildlife Conservation Society. The House agreed to H.R. 2185 by a voice vote today. The Senate companion bill (S. 2020) was reported out favorably by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee on September 11, 2007 and currently awaits a floor vote. The Tropical Forest Conservation Act will expire this year without reauthorization. # # # #
10.04.2007	Two members of Congress today mounted a legal challenge to their national political party over its unprecedented plan to deny up to 4.2 million culturally, socially and economically diverse Florida voters a say in picking the next Democrat nominee for president. share: f t Two members of Congress today mounted a legal challenge to their national political party over its unprecedented plan to deny up to 4.2 million culturally, socially and economically diverse Florida voters a say in picking the next Democrat nominee for president. Florida's senior U.S. Sen. Bill Nelson and the head of the state's U.S. House democratic delegation, Rep. Alcee L. Hastings, filed the lawsuit with other Florida voters in federal court in Tallahassee naming as defendants former Vermont Gov. Howard Dean and the Democratic National Committee Dean heads. The suit contends Dean and the DNC "would impose [voter] disenfranchisement on a massive scale" by stripping Florida of its 210 delegates to the national convention in Denver next year. The DNC imposed that penalty after Florida's Republican-controlled Legislature moved the state's primary to Jan. 29 - jumbling the sequence of first-in-the-nation contests. The suit argues Florida voters have a fundamental right to participate in selecting a presidential nominee. The state's delegates to the national convention are chosen proportionately based on the primary vote. It also contends voters are being denied interaction with presidential candidates, because the DNC has barred campaign appearances in Florida except for private fundraisers. The suit further charges that the defendants are engaging in an election scheme that will result in "impairing minority voter participation," which would be a violation of the Voting Rights Act of 1965. "Every one of the more than 4.25 million registered Democratic voters in Florida will be completely disenfranchised and their constitutional rights ... rendered meaningless," Nelson and Hastings said in the lawsuit. Also named as a defendant in the 26-page complaint is Florida's Secretary of State Kurt Browning, who's job it is to oversee the taxpayer-funded $18 million primary next January. Before filing the lawsuit, Nelson and Hastings offered Dean several alternatives to the DNC punishing Florida, such as getting states with early-primary status to move ahead one week; or, holding a Florida Democratic convention after the primary to formally ratify the vote; or, mounting a last-ditch effort to get state lawmakers to push the primary back a week or so. But Dean, in a Sept. 21 letter, rejected the proposed solutions as not in compliance with national party rules. Dean has said Florida's Jan. 29 primary must be a non-binding beauty contest, and the state party must choose its delegates in a later caucus. The lawsuit asks a federal judge to find that basic legal and constitutional rights of voters are being violated. Although the DNC is a political group, it operates in tandem with the state and performs a public function that directly affects the right of Floridians to have their votes count. Thus, the lawsuit contends, its actions should be subject to the basic protections of the U.S. Constitution. In the past, courts have held that an individual has a constitutional right to vote in a primary election and that a political party cannot take actions that result in denying, diluting or diminishing that vote. The lawsuit argues the right to vote trumps the rights of a political party including to enforce its rules for primary elections. "It's a case of fundamental rights vs. party rules," Nelson said. "As to our right to vote, and have that vote count, there can be no debate," "One would have thought that we wouldn't need this type of discussion 42 years after passage of the Voting Rights Act," said Hastings. "The right to vote and have your vote matter is the cornerstone of our democracy." While the suit speaks for Democrats, Republicans in Florida soon may face a similar problem. National Republican Party leaders are threatening to strip half the state's GOP delegates to its national convention because of the earlier primary date. A permanent solution for primary disputes beyond 2008 requires new legislation, according to both Nelson and Hastings. Nelson, with Sen. Carl Levin, of Michigan, has filed a bill that would divide the nation into six regions, and would establish six primary dates for randomly selected states from each region. Hastings also has introduced legislation with four House colleagues from Florida establishing a rotating regional primary system consisting of four geographic regions whose primary dates rotate over a period of 16 weeks. Both bills would give a fair say in choosing nominees to voters from smaller and larger states, and end the dominance of Iowa and New Hampshire. The dispute over the 2008 primaries is the latest in a series of controversial election problems touching Florida. "In 2000, Florida was the center of an unprecedented and ultimately unsuccessful battle to secure a recount in the presidential election," the lawsuit states. "That extraordinarily intensive process . . . resulted in the rejection of tens of thousands of paper ballots that, if counted, would have changed not just an election, but the future course of national and world events." The lawsuit was filed on behalf of the two lawmakers by Miami attorney Kendall Coffey of Coffey Burlington. # # # The Honorable Alcee L. Hastings Statement on Filing of Election Lawsuit Against the DNC October 4, 2007 The following statement was issued today by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) on the lawsuit that he and Florida's senior Senator Bill Nelson (D) filed today against the Democratic National Committee (DNC) regarding Florida's primary election. "For me, this lawsuit is not about Florida's order in the primary chain. Nor is it about the rules and process at the DNC - however little sense they may make. This lawsuit is about preserving the foundation of our democracy, which remains our right to vote and have that vote count. "Blacks and other minorities in Florida have long faced discrimination at the polls. I would have hoped that we in Florida wouldn't still be talking about preserving one's right to vote 42 years after the passage of the Voting Rights Act...or 7 years after the debacle known as the 2000 election... or less than one year after 18,000 votes went missing - and still are missing - in Sarasota. Yet we are. And that's just sad. "But if my Florida citizenship of 71 years has taught me anything, it is that the struggle continues. Sometimes we need to educate immigrants from Miami. And sometimes even medical doctors from Montpelier, Vermont. Regardless, the struggle continues. "For the DNC to say to the 4th largest contingency of Democrats in the nation that their votes will not matter in next year's presidential primary is not only shocking and ironic, but we believe is illegal. "Realize, it's not just Democrats. The RNC is also poised to strip Florida Republicans of at least half of their delegates for the same the reason the DNC has stripped ours. "There are few issues in this country as paramount as protecting Americans' right to vote and have that vote count. The 30 members of the DNC Rules Committee sitting in some conference room in Washington, DC do not have the authority to steal that right away from Florida's voters. Not yesterday. Not today. Not ever. "We filed this lawsuit with the memories of the mistakes of the past, our hope for the present, and our conviction for a better future. "When Florida voters go to the polls on January 29 to vote for the nominee of their choice, it must not only be a lesson in civic participation, but an exercise in democracy. The further disenfranchisement of Florida voters is just not acceptable." # # # #

Hastings (D-Miramar) led Florida House Democrats today in writing to President George W. Bush urging him to reconsider his plans to veto the Water Resources Development Act (WRDA) of 2007. "When Congress passed the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) in 2000, it committed the Federal government to being an equal partner with the State of Florida to restore the Everglades and protecting the diverse ecosystem that is currently half its original size. However, passage of the water bill has been stymied since 2002, causing severe delays to Everglades' restoration efforts and leaving the federal-state partnership unfulfilled," wrote the Democratic Members.
