The WRDA 2007 bill includes federal authorizations for water infrastructure projects critical to Florida and the nation, including $1.8 billion for Everglades restoration projects, $7.5 million for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in western Palm Beach County, and $1.5 million for a study on expediting structural improvements to the Herbert Hoover Dike surrounding Lake Okeechobee. While in the Majority, Congressional Republicans failed to pass a WRDA since 2002. The bill finally passed both the House and Senate this year with broad bi-partisan support. Nevertheless, President Bush is still threatening to veto this vital bill. The full text of the letter follows: October 2, 2007 The Honorable George W. Bush The White House 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, NW Washington, D.C. 20500 Dear Mr. Bush: As Members of the Florida Congressional Delegation, we write to urge you to reconsider your veto threat of the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007. Among other important nationwide water resources studies and infrastructure projects authorized in this bill, this year's WRDA bill contains water projects vital to the restoration of Florida's Everglades. Preserving and protecting the Everglades is a priority for the State of Florida and is necessary to returning the natural water flow, reviving habitat for more than 60 threatened and endangered species, establishing a reliable water supply for Floridians, and providing flood control to many of our communities. When Congress passed the Comprehensive Everglades Restoration Plan (CERP) in 2000, it committed the Federal government to being an equal partner with the State of Florida to restore the Everglades and protecting the diverse ecosystem that is currently half its original size. However, passage of the water bill has been stymied since 2002, causing severe delays to Everglades' restoration efforts and leaving the federal-state partnership unfulfilled. Nationwide, delays in passing a WRDA bill has created a severe backlog of projects, drastically increasing the costs of the pending water projects. Our State of Florida is already facing significant challenges to funding Everglades restoration efforts. The price of land acquisition and construction materials has escalated since the passage of the last WRDA bill. According to a July report released by the Government Accountability Office, many important Everglades Restoration projects are facing delays-if they are even to get completed at all. You have regularly indicated support for Everglades restoration projects included in the WRDA bill and we thank you. Yet nothing could be more damaging to overall restoration efforts than vetoing this bill. As you know, the current WRDA bill has broad bipartisan based support in Congress. On September 24, 2007, the Senate overwhelming approved the bill by 81 to 12 and on April 19, 2007, the House of Representatives approved the bill by a significant majority of 394 to 25. We urge you to not veto this critical bill that is of extreme significance to the nation's economy and environment, and particularly to preserving and restoring the Everglades. Thank you for your attention. Sincerely, Alcee L. Hastings, M.C. Corrine Brown, M.C. Robert Wexler, M.C. Allen Boyd. M.C. Debbie Wasserman Schultz, M.C. Kendrick B. Meek, M.C. Ron Klein, M.C. 09.21.2007	The House of Representatives today approved the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act of 2007, which includes legislation authored by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) blocking the FAA from moving Palm Beach International Airport's (PBI) Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) system to Miami International Airport (MIA). share: f t The House of Representatives today approved the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) Reauthorization Act of 2007, which includes legislation authored by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) blocking the FAA from moving Palm Beach International Airport's (PBI) Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) system to Miami International Airport (MIA). The bill also requires that PBI's new control tower, on which construction is scheduled to begin later this year, include an operating TRACON. "I've been saying for years that the FAA's TRACON consolidation plan in South Florida runs the grave risk of leaving our air traffic system vulnerable during critical times and setting a dangerous precedent for a process that excludes stakeholders from decisions that impact their lives," said Representative Hastings. "I am not willing to sacrifice safety just to save a few dollars. Eliminating PBI's TRACON is just not safe." The TRACON system guides planes within a 50 mile radius of the airport on their final approaches. In an effort to save money, the FAA has embarked on an ambitious plan to consolidate dozens of TRACON systems throughout the country. Despite overwhelming opposition from the South Florida and Treasure Coast Congressional Delegations and local officials, the FAA is attempting to consolidate the TRACONs of all South Florida international airports into one at MIA. Representative Hastings has warned that under the FAA's plan, all South Florida airports - domestic and international - will be left without an approach radar system if a natural disaster or terrorist attack were to destroy the TRACON at MIA. The FAA's contingency plan would require that controllers in Jacksonville, an airport more than 350 miles away, direct approaching aircraft not only in their assigned region, but throughout all of South Florida and virtually the entire state without additional staff and technology. "With Representative Hastings' leadership, we have secured safety and necessary redundancy in our South Florida air traffic control system in the case of a natural disaster or even worse," said Shane Ahern, President of the National Air Traffic Controllers Association Local at PBI. "The Hastings Amendment will allow for future growth and expansion of air travel in South Florida - which we all know is happening as we speak. Keeping a TRACON at PBI is a huge win for South Florida and the flying public." Representative Hastings has been leading national efforts for the past four years to block the FAA from consolidating America's TRACONs. The House of Representatives has twice adopted amendments authored by Representative Hastings prohibiting the FAA from moving forward on its consolidation plan. After the House voted to block FAA TRACON consolidation in 2006, Republicans refused to complete the Fiscal Year 2007 appropriations process and the Hastings Amendment did not become law. In June 2007, the House again adopted the Hastings Amendment which now awaits action in the Senate. The FAA Reauthorization Act also now awaits Senate action. ####

09.18.2007	U.S. Representative and Florida's Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) led Florida Democrats today in a letter to Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) David Paulison urging him to reconsider FEMA's decision to terminate the Agency's Florida Long-Term Recovery Office and resolve to make the Office permanent. share: f t U.S. Representative and Florida's Congressional Delegation Co-Chairman Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) led Florida Democrats today in a letter to Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) David Paulison urging him to reconsider FEMA's decision to terminate the Agency's Florida Long-Term Recovery Office and resolve to make the Office permanent. "The Florida Long-Term Recovery Office is one of Florida's most important tools we have to respond and mitigate hurricanes and other disasters. It makes zero sense for FEMA to take away our first line of defense against disasters in the middle of an actively predicated hurricane season," said Representative Hastings. "For FEMA to terminate this office that has beyond proven its value and need is a terribly shortsighted approach. FEMA should seriously assess the extent of funding and lives that would be saved by making the office permanent and reconsider its decision." FEMA's Florida Long-Term Recovery Office was established in 2005 in response to the 2004 hurricanes and has since become a crucial underpinning of Florida's efforts to prepare and respond to disasters. For the past two years, work done by the Office has greatly contributed to reduced costs in disaster response as well as the saving of lives. The Office has been successful in expediting recovery efforts and public assistance reimbursements to state and local governments while also providing significant mitigation funding and guidance to local governments working to reduce their risk from future storms. "The Florida Long-Term Recovery Office has proven to be an invaluable asset to the State's ability to prepare and respond to disasters while also providing critical response and mitigation support to the entire Southeast region," wrote Representative Hastings and his colleagues. "The planned closure of this office would not only be premature and ultimately more costly, but could also prove perilous in the likely event of a future hurricane." On May 9, 2007, the House of Representatives unanimously adopted an amendment authored by Representative Hastings that would keep the office open for at least the next three years. Nevertheless, FEMA has announced its continued plan to close the office. A copy of the letter follows. --- September 18, 2007 The Honorable David Paulison Director of the Federal Emergency Management Agency 500 C Street S.W. Washington, D.C. 20472 Dear Director Paulison, We write to urge the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to ensure that the FEMA Florida Long-Term Recovery Office in Orlando, Florida, remains open. As you know, on May 9, 2007, the House of Representatives went on record in unanimous agreement that the Florida Long-Term Recovery Office should remain open for a period of at least three years. The planned closure of this office would not only be premature and ultimately more costly, but could also prove perilous in the likely event of a future hurricane. To that end, we respectfully request that you reconsider your decision to terminate the Florida Long-Term Recovery Office and resolve to make the office permanent. Created in response to the hurricanes of 2004, Florida's Long-Term Recovery Office has become a vital component of our state's efforts to cope with and respond to the hurricanes and tropical storms which constantly threaten the state. For example, the full- time recovery staff, well-versed in state and federal policies, has rectified mistakes made by previous emergency management teams. Moreover, the permanencies of the staff and the relationships they have cultivated with local governments, non-profits, communities, and federal officials have increased efficiency of benefit distribution and decreased response times to disasters, saving both lives and taxpayer dollars. The more permanent office has also taken preventative steps to mitigate the impact of future disasters through pilot projects, and partnerships they have built over time. While no dollar amount can be placed on the lives saved through the efficient and immediate disaster response of a local standing office, such an office will prove to save thousands in costs associated with terminating and then re-establishing an office every time a disaster strikes Florida. Leaving aside the consistency in staffing and decision making and thorough knowledge of the Florida landscape developed in a standing operation, the cost of travel, lodging, and other expenses associated with deploying an emergency response operation are nearly two and a half times the cost of the standing operation. When neither the local nor state emergency management offices have sufficient funding to handle disasters, the burden to assist the disaster ridden communities, consequently, falls on the Federal government. Given the nearly $80 billion Congress passed in emergency supplemental appropriations as a result of the 2004 and 2005 hurricane seasons, it is crucial to not only find ways to respond to disasters more quickly, but also to do so in the most cost efficient manner. A more permanent FEMA Long-Term Recovery Office has continued to provide numerous benefits not only to Florida, but to the entire nation. In only its first four months of existence, the Office was able to more than double its ability to reimburse recipients for public assistance, from $1 billion to over $2 billion, notwithstanding the fact that the office was dealing with additional storms at the time. Since the Long-Term Recovery Office opened in Florida, more mitigation funds have gone out to recipients than ever before in FEMA's history. The Long-Term Recovery Office has also closed down two large scale housing missions - something never accomplished in all of FEMA's history. Even more, many of the Office's successful techniques first tried in Florida are now being employed throughout the Gulf Coast with equal success. One argument that has been used by you and others at FEMA against making the Long-Term Recovery Office in Florida permanent has been the Agency's opposition to permanent field offices. We note, however, that recently a FEMA Long-Term Recovery Office has been established in Alaska as part of the Fiscal Year 2007 Homeland Security Appropriations Act. In 2006, Congress also established Long-Term Recovery Offices in Mississippi, Louisiana, Alabama and Texas. As a disaster prone state that has suffered from devastating hurricanes in the last few years, doesn't it make good policy sense for Florida to have a permanent Long-Term Recovery Office as well? The Florida Long-Term Recovery Office has proven to be an invaluable asset to the State's ability to prepare and respond to disasters while also providing critical response and mitigation support to the entire Southeast region. This season, forecasters have predicted as many as five major hurricanes, many which will likely impact our state. Therefore, we respectfully request that you keep Florida's Long-Term Recovery Office, essential to both Floridians and to the America people, permanently open. Thank you for considering this very important request. We look forward to your expeditious response. Sincerely, Alcee L. Hastings Member of Congress Corrine Brown Member of Congress Debbie Wasserman Schultz Member of Congress Ron Klein Member of Congress Kendrick B. Meek Member of Congress Robert Wexler Member of Congress Allen Boyd Member of Congress Tim Mahoney Member of Congress Kathy Castor Member of Congress ####
09.06.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced legislation establishing a regional presidential primary system, ensuring that voters in every state have an equal opportunity to decide America's presidential candidates. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced legislation establishing a regional presidential primary system, ensuring that voters in every state have an equal opportunity to decide America's presidential candidates. Representative Hastings' bill, the Regional Presidential Primary and Caucus Act of 2007, is being introduced while Florida's Republican and Democratic state parties find themselves at odds with their national parties which are attempting to strip the state parties of their delegates at their 2008 national conventions. "Today's Presidential primary system is broken. There is no one state in this country that is more important than the next, and the thought that New Hampshire and Iowa are guaranteed to go first is absolutely asinine," said Representative Hastings. "Establishing a new regional primary system by which Americans can select their presidential nominees is the future. If the national parties are blind to this reality, then Congress must open up their eyes." The Regional Presidential Primary and Caucus Act of 2007 establishes four geographic regions and four regional primary/caucus dates in each presidential election year. Under the bill, beginning in 2012 and on a rotating basis during each presidential election year, states in one region will hold their presidential primary elections on the first Tuesday in March. States in the next region will hold their primary elections on the first Tuesday in April, states in the next region on the first Tuesday in May, and states in the final region on the first Tuesday of June. The order of regions will rotate in each of the four years, ensuring that all states have the opportunity to hold their primary election first in the cycle once every four presidential elections. "Out of this year's mess can and must come sound public policy. Primary elections were never intended to pit one state against another. At the end of the day, all votes must be counted and all votes must actually count," Representative Hastings stated. "The regional primary system which I and others are proposing is fair, equitable and reliable. It treats every state equally and ensures that voters from every corner of the U.S. will not be disenfranchised by an outdated primary system." Representative Hastings' bill is the companion bill to S. 1905, which was introduced by Senators Amy Klobuchar (D-MN), Joe Lieberman (I-CT), and Lamar Alexander (R-TN). ####
09.06.2007	U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Ron Klein (D-Boca Raton) sent a letter today to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) expressing concern over the sharp rise of wild Burmese pythons in and around the Everglades National Park. share: f t U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) and Ron Klein (D-Boca Raton) sent a letter today to the Director of the United States Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) expressing concern over the sharp rise of wild Burmese pythons in and around the Everglades National Park. The Burmese python is an exotic constrictor species that has been found breeding in increasing numbers in natural areas of Southern Florida. More than 350 of the South Asian snakes have been found invading the park since 2002, with others appearing along Florida's west coast and farther north in Florida. Invasive species such as this python have the potential to adversely affect Everglades restoration efforts and all of the ecosystem's inhabitants. "The increasing presence of the Burmese pythons in the Everglades and surrounding areas engenders a very real, expensive, and dangerous problem for Florida and the entire nation. The pythons directly threaten the endangered species and plants of this unique ecosystem, and importantly, the people visiting and living in the Everglades and surrounding communities. The Federal government must act immediately and appropriately to address this escalating danger," said Representative Hastings. "When I was elected, I promised to make Everglades restoration a top priority. Thus far, Congress has come through by authorizing billions of dollars for various projects in the Water Resources Development Act of 2007. But preserving the indigenous species of the Everglades is also a critical component of Everglades restoration. That's why we must address the Burmese python population. Recent reports show that the population appears to be growing in the Everglades, putting in jeopardy a wide variety of natural species. The U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service must act now and list the Burmese python as an injurious species so that federal and state efforts to control the Everglades python population can have an impact," said Representative Klein. The letter sent by Representatives Hastings and Klein urges the USFWS to immediately consider adding the pythons to a list of "injurious species" under the Lacey Act, prohibiting the importation of the pythons into the country as well as interstate transportation. The letter also recommends the creation of a task force to evaluate the USFWS' injurious listing process top reduce backlogs and expedite the process. A copy of the letter follows. --- September 5, 2007 Mr. H. Dale Hall, Director United States Fish and Wildlife Service 1849 C Street, N.W. Mailstop 3238 MIB Washington, DC 20240 Dear Mr. Hall: We write to express our support for the Burmese python injurious animal petition submitted to your office on June 23, 2006 under the Lacey Act (42 U.S.C. §18). As you know, the Lacey Act's injurious wildlife provision serves as the primary regulatory safeguard from invasive animal species introductions in the United States. Given the well-documented increases in wild Burmese python sightings in and around the Florida Everglades and the recent discovery of the federally-endangered Key Largo wood rat in the stomach of a Burmese python, the United States Fish and Wildlife Serve (USFWS) should take immediate action and fast track the injurious wildlife review of this harmful invasive species. State and federal agencies, including the USFWS, have been rushing to develop and implement python control programs in Florida before this species becomes more widespread. Unfortunately, Burmese pythons continue to be legally imported in astonishing numbers. Since 2000, over 67,000 Burmese pythons have been imported into the United States. Restricting importation of the Burmese python will not in itself remove the established python population in Florida. Nevertheless, if we are to successfully control this emerging threat, all segments of the introduction pathway, particularly importation should be addressed. We also strongly encourage you to begin an internal review of the USFWS' injurious animal listing process. According to a recent analysis of the USFWS' regulatory program, the average time between initiation and final actions of listing reviews has increased from less than one year during the mid-1900s to over four years in the last decade. We recognize that substantial resources are required to properly complete these reviews and are well aware of the financial limitations under which the USFWS regulatory branch finds itself. However, the Lacey Act cannot be effective if regulatory reviews are not completed in a timely fashion. To this end, we respectfully request that a task force be formed to review the USFWS' injurious listing process and promptly make recommendations to ensure that the Lacey Act is implemented commensurate with the contemporary challenges we face with invasive species. Thank you for your consideration of our requests. If you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us. We look forward to your expeditious response. Sincerely, s/ Alcee L. Hastings s/ Ron Klein Member of Congress Member of Congress # # # #
08.29.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today announced that the U.S. Department of Transportation is awarding a $9 million grant to Ft. Lauderdale Executive Airport (FXE) to relocate a parallel taxiway that currently does not meet the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) runway safety requirements. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today announced that the U.S. Department of Transportation is awarding a $9 million grant to Ft. Lauderdale Executive Airport (FXE) to relocate a parallel taxiway that currently does not meet the Federal Aviation Administration's (FAA) runway safety requirements. "This grant will help ensure the future safety of all of those who use Ft. Lauderdale Executive Airport every day," said Representative Hastings. "FXE is an important part of the South Florida transportation network and economy. I am so pleased that the federal government is making this necessary investment in the airport and encouraging its continued growth to meet the needs of the flying public." Representative Hastings was instrumental two years ago in convincing U.S. Customs and Border Patrol (CBP) officials to expand customs hours at FXE. Increased CBP hours at FXE allowed the airport to meet increased demand and assisted in the elimination of flight diversions to Ft. Lauderdale/Hollywood International Airport (FLL), immediately reducing traffic movements at FLL by as much as 6%, or nearly 8,000 flights per year. # # # #
08.29.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (FL-23) and U.S. Representative Tim Mahoney (FL-16) called on the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to ensure that an adequate supply of safe emergency housing would be available in the event of a disaster in Florida in a letter to FEMA Director Paulison. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (FL-23) and U.S. Representative Tim Mahoney (FL-16) called on the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) to ensure that an adequate supply of safe emergency housing would be available in the event of a disaster in Florida in a letter to FEMA Director Paulison. In response to recent reports that the travel trailers FEMA was using to temporarily house disaster victims in the Gulf Coast contained high levels of formaldehyde, FEMA decided to temporarily suspend the installation, sale, transfer or donation of travel trailers or park model recreational vehicles currently in its inventory. To date, FEMA has not provided the starting or ending dates for the air quality testing of the travel trailers or information on what alternative forms of emergency housing are being considered in the event the travel trailers are not available at the time the next disaster strikes. 08.20.2007	Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe sends letter to Secretary Rice calling on U.S. to make a serious commitment in helping Iraqi refugees and internally displaced populations. share: f t Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (U.S. Helsinki Commission) and Special Representative on Mediterranean Affairs for the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly, sent the following letter to Secretary of State Condoleezza Rice, expressing grave concern over the massive displacement of Iraqis and the impending humanitarian crisis rapidly ensuing in the region. In particular, the letter highlights the need for the United States to address this devastating situation with strong financial support, either through bilateral assistance or funding for international organizations that are working directly with the refugee and internally displaced populations. In addition, the letter requests that Secretary Rice provide Congress with updates on the progress made to date by the Iraq Refugee and Internally Displaced Persons Task Force and other divisions of the U.S. Department of State. Currently, Iraqis are the third-largest displaced population in the world and the fastest-growing refugee population globally. The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimates that there are some 2.2 million Iraqis displaced internally and at least another 2.5 million Iraqis who have sought refuge in neighboring countries such as Jordan and Syria. (Please find below a copy of the letter) August 20, 2007 The Honorable Condoleezza Rice Secretary of State U.S. Department of State 2201 C Street NW Washington, DC 20520 Dear Secretary Rice: As Special Representative on Mediterranean Affairs for the Parliamentary Assembly of the OSCE, I write with grave concern regarding the massive displacement of Iraqis and the impending humanitarian crisis rapidly ensuing in the region. I have traveled extensively to the region, including a visit to Jordan in May of this year where I learned first hand of the plight of the refugees and their impact on the society and government of Jordan, and I believe the United States has a moral obligation to spearhead efforts to assist the growing Iraqi refugee populations. As you know, Madam Secretary, continuing sectarian violence in Iraq has forced a mass migration of Iraqis from their homes. Iraqis are now the third-largest displaced population in the world and the fastest-growing refugee population globally. The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) estimates that there are some 2.2 million Iraqis displaced internally and at least another 2.5 million Iraqis have sought refuge in neighboring countries such as Jordan and Syria. The flood of Iraqi refugees has created a huge burden on the resources of primarily the Jordanian and Syrian governments, while Lebanon, Egypt and other neighboring countries are impacted as well. Jordan currently hosts an estimated Iraqi refugee population of 750,000. This influx is alarming in a country of just 6 million people, especially considering the increasing presence of Islamic militants in Jordan over the last decade. While Jordanian leaders and many local and international non-governmental groups are taking significant steps to respond to the refugees' basic needs, education, health care and even water access remain limited. As you know, in January, Jordan closed its borders to Iraqis because it cannot absorb more people into this resource-poor kingdom. Despite this, Jordan has not seen significantly increased economic assistance from its top ally - the United States - to fund its schools, hospitals, and public infrastructure. Syria, as well, is straining under the pressure of hosting 2.5 million Iraqi refugees, as it is the only country which has kept its border open. According to the Syrian government, Syria spends more than $830,000,000 per year for registered Iraqi students to attend school, and receive medical treatment and food. In addition, according to the government, Syria spends approximately $1.8 billion per year to subsidize food, heating oil, gasoline, electrical power and water for the Iraqi refugees. As a result of soaring rent costs, overcrowded schools, rising crime, health problems, and concerns about the vulnerability of young, unemployed Iraqis to extremist influences, Syria is now struggling to absorb these refugees. The security situation in Jordan, Syria, and other host countries is rapidly deteriorating. Tension is rising among host communities, oversaturated with displaced populations, who, themselves, lack access to basic services, and Iraqi refugees angered by their deteriorating life circumstances. The destabilizing nature of large refugee flows, the need to enroll children in school so they won't remain idle, and the skewing of sectarian balances in host countries may very well lead to a breakdown of law and order in the host countries. In a July 26, 2007 meeting of several of the host countries' leaders to address the Iraqi refugee crisis, Jordanian delegates estimated they would need more than $1 billion in emergency assistance and Syria estimated they would need more than $250 million in similar assistance to adequately ensure an effective degree of security within their respective countries and to safeguard their borders. If the United States does not make a serious commitment to help the Iraqi refugee populations in these countries soon, terrorist groups may fill the void in these areas of need. The United States has a responsibility to provide leadership in addressing this expanding humanitarian crisis. I appreciate that our government has already taken several measures to address this dire situation, including establishing the Iraq Refugee and Internally Displaced Persons Task Force in February of this year. I am, nevertheless, concerned that we are not doing enough. A larger part of the United States' efforts to address the devastating refugee situation must derive from strong financial support, either through bilateral assistance or funding for international organizations that are working directly with the refugee and internally displaced populations. Jordan clearly needs additional bilateral aid to deal with the growing humanitarian and security concerns resulting from the massive influx of Iraqi refugees. I respectfully request that a significant amount of any future monies appropriated to Jordan, other unrestricted host countries, and legitimate international organizations working in the region is specifically designated for refugee assistance. I would also appreciate receiving from you an update on the progress made to date by the Task Force and other divisions of the State Department in addressing the Iraq refugee crisis. Clearly, the prolonged massive displacement of Iraqi citizens has the potential to lead to a broader regional crisis with major security implications. I urge your increased attention to the Iraq refugee and IDP crisis and look forward to your prompt response. Sincerely, Alcee L. Hastings, M.C. Chairman ### The Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, also known as the Helsinki Commission, is a U.S. Government agency that monitors progress in the implementation of the provisions of the 1975 Helsinki Accords. The Commission consists of nine members from the United States Senate, nine from the House of Representatives, and one member each from the Departments of State, Defense and Commerce.
08.03.2007	Calls President Bush's Veto Threat "irresponsible and foolhardy." U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) hailed yesterday's passage of the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007 which included an authorization of $7.5 million for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in Palm Beach County and several other critical Everglades Restoration projects. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) hailed yesterday's passage of the Water Resource Development Act (WRDA) of 2007 which included an authorization of $7.5 million for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant in Palm Beach County and several other critical Everglades Restoration projects. Although not originally included in the House WRDA bill, Representative Hastings successfully secured the authorization for the project in the Conference Report. The Lake Region Water Treatment Plant is being constructed to serve the underserved Glades communities, and Representative Hastings has made it one of his top priorities to secure federal funding for the Plant. "This authorization reaffirms the Federal commitment to build the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant and opens the door for larger Federal appropriations to help fund it," said Representative Hastings, "the construction of this plant is critical to ensuring the people of Western Palm Beach County and in the Glades have access to clean water to drink at affordable rates. No one should be without clean affordable water." Palm Beach County Commissioner Jess R. Santamaria, who represents the Glades region, also voiced his appreciation for the inclusion of the authorization for the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant, noting, "Congressman Hastings has for many years recognized the importance of providing clean water for the residents of the Glades and again has capitalized on his position in The United States House of Representatives to help make the Lake Region Water Treatment Plant a reality." As Co-Chairman of Florida's Congressional Delegation, Representatives Hastings was also successful in leading efforts to securing federal authorizations for $1.8 billion to restore the Everglades, a unique national treasure. The Conference Report included authorization for three vital Everglades restoration projects: the Indian River Lagoon Project, the Picayune Strand Restoration Project, and the Site 1 Impoundment Project in Broward, Palm Beach, and Miami-Dade Counties. The Conference Report also included language modifying the cost increases for several previously authorized projects, totaling an additional $6 million dollars and the expedited completion of the Modified Water Deliveries Project to accelerate the natural flow of water into the Everglades. Finally, the Conference Report includes $1.5 million for a study of the future sustainability of the Herbert Hoover Dike. "My colleagues from Florida and I have been pushing Congress for years to authorize these vital Everglades projects. This new Congress made passing WRDA a priority and I am pleased that the Conference Report includes billions of dollars crucial to my district and the entire State of Florida to help protect and restore the Everglades' diverse ecosystem," Representative Hastings said. "Today's success builds upon previous Everglades Restoration funding successes of this year. With the passage of this bill, the federal-state partnership-long ignored by previous Congresses-will now be restored." Congress has not approved a water resources bill since 2000. The House overwhelmingly approved the WRDA Conference Report late yesterday evening. President Bush has already issued a veto threat for this bill. "The President's veto threat of WRDA is further proof of how out of touch he is with the priorities of this country," said Representative Hastings. "I sincerely hope that he'll reconsider his position. It would be irresponsible and foolhardy of him to veto a bill that is so desperately needed in South Florida and throughout the country." ####
07.26.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) adds two crucial amendments to Transportation-HUD Appropriations for FY 2008, which will have major positive impacts for South Florida. share: f t The House of Representatives late last night passed the Transportation, Treasury, and Housing and Urban Development Appropriations bill for Fiscal Year 2008 after adopting two amendments authored by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (FL-23) which, if signed into law, will have major positive impacts on South Florida. The House unanimously adopted an amendment authored by Representative Hastings allocating no less than $20 million for safety and security in public housing communities throughout the country. Representative Hastings offered his amendment just weeks after a woman was gang raped and she and her son beaten in Dunbar Village in West Palm Beach. Until 2002, the Public Housing Drug Elimination Program existed under the Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD). However, in 2001, the Bush Administration announced that the Program had a limited impact and did not reflect HUD's core mission. Since then, the Administration has maintained that it is not responsible for providing security at its public housing facilities. When the Drug Elimination Program was consolidated with HUD's Public Housing Operating Fund, a grant of $168,000 for security services was cut from the West Palm Beach Housing Authority, which oversees Dunbar Village. "As a result of this attack and recent escalation of crime at Dunbar, people in this community are literally afraid to come out of their homes," said Representative Hastings during consideration of his amendment. "Unfortunately, it takes action such as this one for us to open our eyes and for Congress to begin reversing funding trends and program adjustments that have left our communities vulnerable." The House also overwhelmingly approved another amendment authored by Representative Hastings blocking the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) from moving Palm Beach International Airport's Terminal Radar Approach Control (TRACON) system to Miami International Airport. The final vote tally for Representative Hastings' amendment was 268-158. During debate on his amendment, Representative Hastings noted that the FAA's plan would leave all South Florida airports without an approach radar system if a natural disaster or terrorist attack were to destroy MIA's TRACON. The FAA's contingency plan, as presented to Representative Hastings, would require that controllers in Jacksonville, an airport more than 350 miles away, direct approaching aircraft not only in their assigned region, but throughout all of South Florida and virtually the entire state without additional staff and technology. The House approved the same amendment last year authored by Representative Hastings, but it was never signed into law and the FAA accelerated its consolidation efforts in South Florida. "This is not a question of whether or not consolidation can technologically be done. It can be done, and it is being done. On the contrary, this is a question of should it be done and what is Congress willing to risk," Representative Hastings said during debate on his amendment. "The FAA's TRACON consolidation runs the grave risk of leaving our air traffic system vulnerable during critical times and setting a dangerous precedent for a process that excludes stakeholders from decisions that impact their lives. This is not a risk that Congress should be willing to take." Both amendments now await Senate consideration. ####
07.26.2007	U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced the Path to Success Act, legislation which will promote community-centered partnerships to combat gang violence. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) today introduced the Path to Success Act, legislation which will promote community-centered partnerships to combat gang violence. "The Path to Success Act serves as an important piece of legislation to address a pressing social dilemma that has permeated American society, successfully wreaking havoc, fear, and violence indiscriminately in urban and rural communities alike," said Representative Hastings when introducing the bill today. "Gang related offenses have peaked to astronomical numbers, making youth gangs an endemic feature of American life. Most of these gang members are engulfed in a cyclical culture of poverty, illiteracy, and homelessness which contribute to excessive recidivism rates." In an effort to reduce recidivism rates among juvenile ex-offenders, Representative Hastings' bill authorizes the Secretary of Education to award grants to community colleges that agree to enter into and maintain partnerships with juvenile detention centers by providing juvenile ex-offenders with a supportive learning environment where they can attain marketable skills and credentials needed for the constructive re-entry into society. Under the bill, Community Colleges will work with different partners to employ intervention strategies to divert at-risk youth from crime by providing counseling, academic or vocational training, and professional development to eligible participants enrolled in the program. "By promoting communal networks, the Path to Success Act provides opportunities for the community to be instrumental in administering programs designed to reduce recidivism among ex-gang offenders and deter gang violence and membership among other at risk youths," noted Representative Hastings. "It is impossible for one agency to unilaterally solve intractable problems. That is exactly why every worthwhile effort requires collaboration and partnering among organizations to resolve the issue we see before us in this day and age. It is with this understanding that this legislation cultivates partner-centric approaches to mitigate and eventually eliminate gang violence and membership." ####
07.23.2007	The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously passed the National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom Reauthorization Act of 2007 (H.R. 1239) which protects the currently jeopardized Network to Freedom of the National Park Service by providing $2.5 million annually for the Network and related grants. share: f t The U.S. House of Representatives today unanimously passed the National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom Reauthorization Act of 2007 (H.R. 1239) which was introduced by U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar). The legislation protects the currently jeopardized National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom of the National Park Service by providing $2.5 million annually for the Network and related grants. "The Network to Freedom is a key feature that diversifies engagement in interpretive opportunities of our national park system," said Representative Hastings. "Black history is American history, and it is time for us to take a stand for the future of our National Parks and American history." Established by Congress in 1998, the Network to Freedom currently encompasses 300 affiliate sites, facilities, and program nationally in 28 states and the District of Columbia. Interest in the history of the Underground Railroad continues to increase, but a projected budget shortfall of more than 79% by 2011 could result in staffing shortages that would diminish collaboration between the Network affiliates. Representative Hastings' bill remedies the shortfall by authorizing more operating funds for administrative support. "In this polarized historical moment of American politics, remembering the Underground Railroad as a unifying narrative in our history could not be timelier," Representative Hastings said on the House floor today. "The sacrifice at the risk of death made by conductors and travelers of the Underground Railroad was an unprecedented contribution to the abolition of slavery. I am confident that this bill will protect the interpretive interests of our National Park System by providing the necessary support staff and oversight for the Network to Freedom to exist in perpetuity." # # # # Representative Hastings introduced H.R. 1239 with Representative Michael Castle (R-DE) and 26 other original cosponsors. The bill passed with 67 bi-partisan cosponsors.

Hastings (FL-23) and Congressman Tim Mahoney (FL-16) today announced the awarding of a $1.3 million federal grant for runway construction at the St. Lucie County International Airport. Hastings (FL-23) and Congressman Tim Mahoney (FL-16) today announced the awarding of a $1.3 million federal grant for runway construction at the St. Lucie County International Airport. The grant was awarded by the U.S. Department of Transportation. "St. Lucie International will play a critical role in the future growth and successes of the Treasure Coast. This grant, which will help expand operations at the airport without sacrificing flight training schools, is a welcomed step forward. Most importantly, it is represents a responsible and safe approach toward growing the airport," said Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (FL-23). "This federal grant will help the St. Lucie Airport improve safety and operations for the benefit of our community. It is important that the airport continue to plan for future needs by improving infrastructure and enhancing their ability to adjust to the needs of travelers coming into and out of St. Lucie. This grant will assist the airport in doing just that," said Congressman Tim Mahoney. "The efforts of Congressmen Alcee Hastings and Tim Mahoney are much appreciated for their support in securing funding of an additional $1.3 million to continue construction on a new runway and parallel taxiway at the St. Lucie County International Airport. This new runway will enhance safety by separating training operations from the main airfield area, add capacity to meet future needs, and provide a benefit for those communities impacted by noise from training traffic," said Diana D. Lewis, Airport Director, St. Lucie County International Airport. The funding will be used to enhance safety and capacity at St. Lucie County International Airport by constructing an additional runway and taxiway system that will be used for flight training. In addition, the funding will be used to relocate a Florida Power and light transmission line associated with the construction of the runway. 07.19.2007	An expert panel will engage in a community discussion to dispel myths, expand prevention outreach, improve treatment, and address policy issues. share: f t U.S. Representative Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) announced today that he will host "Reclaiming Our Community: Combating HIV/AIDS in Our Backyard," a public forum and discussion on Saturday, July 28, 2007. The event will be held at the African American Research Library in Ft. Lauderdale from 1:00 PM-2:30 PM. This community discussion will address alarming statistics on the reported HIV/AIDS cases in Florida. This event is a much needed response to recent statistics which reveal that African Americans are still disproportionately affected by the disease. Even more distressing, statistics have shown that African-American women are the most vulnerable group. Overall, Florida currently ranks third in the nation in the number of HIV/AIDS cases, with some of the highest reported cases occurring in Broward, Palm Beach and Miami-Dade Counties. An expert panel will discuss means to dispel myths, expand prevention outreach, improve treatment, and address policy issues. Representatives from the following agencies have already confirmed their participation: United States Department of Health and Human Services (HHS); Florida Department of Health Bureau of HIV/AIDS; Broward County Health Department; and Racial and Ethnic Approaches to Community Health (REACH 2010). "I encourage community leaders, organizations, and the general public to come out and support this important and timely event," said Representative Hastings. "It is imperative that we dispel the myths and misperceptions about the issue and implement community centered approaches to curtail this epidemic. HIV/AIDS has had devastating effects on our lives across community lines. All of us must work together to reduce the racial and ethnic disparities that we unfortunately encounter all too often with this disease. I hope we take this event as an opportunity to learn, participate, and help our district take legitimate measures to advocate the plights of those infected and affected by this fatal disease." Individuals with questions should contact Representative Hastings' Ft. Lauderdale office at (954) 733-2800. # # # #
07.17.2007	Representative Hastings secures desperately needed rehabilitation funds for the dike which protects communities along the shores of Lake Okeechobee. share: f t WASHINGTON, DC - The House of Representatives is set today to approve the Energy and Water Appropriations Bill for Fiscal Year 2008 which includes $55.8 million secured by U.S. Representatives Alcee L. Hastings (D-Miramar) for repairs to the Herbert Hoover Dike. The Dike, which is in desperate need of rehabilitation, was built in the 1930s to protect those living in the communities along the shores of Lake Okeechobee. "My constituents who reside in the communities surrounding the Herbert Hoover Dike are well aware of the potential for the Herbert Hoover Dike to fail and the subsequent catastrophic flooding in South Florida that would ensue," said Representative Hastings. "I am pleased that the House of Representatives realized the dire need to provide for the safety and security of communities in the Glades and around the Lake region. After today, the House will be on record in support of the necessary funding to expeditiously repair the Dike. I hope the Senate will follow suit and include this vital funding in its bill as well. I will be doing everything in my power to urge them to do just that. We can not afford another day to go by without acting." U.S. Representative Tim Mahoney (FL-16), who represents western portions of Lake Okeechobee, also voiced support for this important rehabilitation project. "I would like to thank Congressman Hastings for helping to secure this important funding for the Herbert Hoover Dike," said Representative Mahoney. "The Herbert Hoover Dike is in need of rehabilitation in order to protect against possible flooding in the event of a major storm. This funding meets the Army Corps of Engineers request for funding for fiscal year 2008 and is a major victory for our community." Since the deadly hurricanes of 1928, governments at all levels have joined together to maintain safe levels for Lake Okeechobee and construct and operate the Herbert Hoover Dike, which surrounds the Lake. The Army Corps of Engineers and the South Florida Water Management District have realized that the Dike - constructed over 70 years ago -is deteriorating and could potentially fail under extreme circumstances and stress. Representative Hastings has been working since 2005 with all officials at all levels of government to develop and implement a comprehensive plan to rehabilitate the Dike and prevent any possible flooding of the surrounding communities. The impacts of the 2004-2005 hurricane season on the Dike, combined with the dike failures during Hurricane Katrina and a May 2006 SFWMD report describing the Dike as posing a "grave and imminent danger," have brought increased attention to well-being of the Herbert Hoover Dike and the potential for its failure. Representatives Hastings and Mahoney were also successful in securing $4 million in funding for completing construction of the St. Lucie Inlet in Martin County. Additionally, under the leadership of Representative Hastings and others, the House Energy and Water Appropriations bill also includes $162.5 million for South Florida Everglades Ecosystem restoration efforts. The House is expected to approve the Energy and Water Appropriations bill later today. The bill awaits action in the Senate and an eventual Conference Report which Congress hopes to complete before September 30, 2007. # # # #
07.13.2007	Post Trip Analysis of Political Situation, Bilateral Meetings and Visits to Babi Yar and Famine-Genocide Memorials and the Chornobyl Zone share: f t From July 5 to 9, 2007, Congressman Alcee L. Hastings (D-FL), Chairman of the Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe (U.S. Helsinki Commission) and Co-Chairman Senator Benjamin L. Cardin (D-MD) and House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer (D-MD), a former Chair of the U.S. Helsinki Commission led a Congressional delegation to Ukraine for the 16th Annual Session of the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe's (OSCE) Parliamentary Assembly. House Majority Leader Hoyer was the highest ranking Member of Congress to ever attend the session and was joined by U.S. Helsinki Commissioners Representatives Robert B. Aderholt (R-AL), G.K. Butterfield (D-NC), Mike McIntyre (D-NC), Louise McIntosh Slaughter (D-NY), Christopher H. Smith (R-NJ) and Hilda L. Solis (D-CA) as well as Representatives Marcy Kaptur (D-OH), Doris Matsui (D-CA), Michael McNulty (D-NY) and Gwen Moore (D-WI). On July 9, the OSCE PA adopted the Kyiv Declaration, which expresses regret at the lack of progress in resolving so-called "frozen conflicts" in the OSCE region and recommends strengthened action in several fields including migration and energy and environmental security, anti-Semitism and democracy in Belarus. This Declaration is the result of five days of work by the 250 parliamentarians who participated in the session and will be sent to the governments of the 56 OSCE participating States. (For more information on the Kyiv Declaration, please visit http://www.oscepa.org/) While in Kyiv, the delegation held direct talks with President Viktor Yushchenko on the political situation in Ukraine. "It was clear from our meeting with the President that the state of affairs here remains unsettled. And while the situation is not resolved, it is important to note an agreement has been reached, which I and my colleagues in the delegation welcome. The May 27 agreement resolves this political crisis through pre-term parliamentary elections scheduled for September 30, and it is my sincere hope that this extremely important agreement is honored and implemented," said Chairman Hastings. House Majority Leader Hoyer added, "This trip comes at an important time in Ukrainian history; however, our message is clear. The people of Ukraine deserve to participate in free and fair elections to ensure the integrity of their democratic process continues to be preserved and protected." Members of the delegation also visited the Babi Yar Memorial with Rabbi Alexander Duchovny, Chief Progressive Rabbi of Kyiv and the Ukraine Union of the Progressive Jewish Congregations, where they laid a wreath in tribute to the more than 100,000 Ukrainians killed there during World War II - including 33,000 Jews from Kyiv that were shot in a two-day period in September 1941. This was one of the worst massacres of the Holocaust. In addition, the delegation visited the Famine-Genocide Memorial (1932-33), where they met with survivor Eugenia Dallas. Ms. Dallas spoke of her experience as a famine survivor and what she had to do in order to survive. The memorial is dedicated to the millions of Ukrainians who died in one of the largest man-made famines to take place during the 20th century. Congressman McIntyre noted, "I was touched by Ms. Dallas' story and by visiting this memorial. It is imperative that we raise awareness here in Washington of this terrible tragedy in an effort to ensure that this never happens again." The delegation also hosted a reception for parliamentarians from the United Kingdom and Canada where Chairman Hastings noted, "I am proud to stand with my friends from Canada, the United Kingdom and United States and I believe that it is important to recognize the long historical bonds our nations share. This historic partnership has faced challenges in the past; however the United States stands shoulder to shoulder with Britain and Canada and looks forward to continuing this unbreakable bond." The delegation also travelled to Chornobyl and visited the site where on April 26, 1986, the fourth reactor of the Chornobyl Nuclear Power Plant exploded, releasing radioactive materials across Europe. While in Chornobyl the group visited the "ghost town" of Pripyat located right next to the nuclear plant, where after the explosion in 1986, its nearly 50,000 residents were told that they must leave immediately only taking their passports and money, never to return again. Senator Cardin noted, "I am very pleased to have travelled to Chornobyl to witness first hand what took place here in 1986. The devastation of this explosion will never be forgotten, but I am glad to see that the Chornobyl Nuclear Plant is at a turning point and is working to repair the damage that was done." In addition, the delegation also held bilateral meetings with parliamentarians of the Russian Duma, Ukrainian parliamentarians, as well as with parliamentary delegations from the Mediterranean Partners for Cooperation. Lastly, during the Annual Session, Congresswoman Hilda Solis was elected as Vice Chair of the General Committee on Democracy, Human Rights and Humanitarian Questions for the OSCE PA. This Committee is responsible for addressing humanitarian and human rights-related threats to security and serves as a forum for examining the potential for cooperation within these areas. Congressman Hastings and Senator Cardin noted, "Hilda's two decades of public service is truly exemplified by her commitment to the guiding principles of the OSCE. In Congress, she has been a leader in the bipartisan Congressional Caucus for Women's Issues and is an outspoken advocate for issues of importance to women and families. Hilda has also continued to play a tremendous role on the OSCE PA forum on gender issues. We are honored to serve with Hilda on the U.S. Helsinki Commission and know that she will be an excellent representative of the United States in her new post." ### The Commission on Security and Cooperation in Europe, also known as the Helsinki Commission, is a U.S. Government agency that monitors progress in the implementation of the provisions of the 1975 Helsinki Accords. The Commission consists of nine members from the United States Senate, nine from the House of Representatives, and one member each from the Departments of State, Defense and Commerce.

Hastings (D-Miramar) dedicating $1 million to preserve the National Underground Network to Freedom. The amendment serves as an extension of the ongoing work that Representative Hastings has been doing to ensure that Underground Railroad sites are preserved for future generations. "Members on both sides of the aisle agree that the National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom is a phenomenal resource of the National Park Service," said Representative Hastings on the House floor. "Our amendment is not just about preserving black history. It is about preserving American history, and we cannot let our history be forgotten. In addition to this amendment, the Interior and Environment Appropriations bill also includes over $200 million championed by Representative Hastings and others for the continued restoration of Florida's Everglades. The House also defeated an attempt to further open up Florida's coasts to off-shore oil drilling. At the request of Representatives Hastings and Hilda Solis (D-CA), the bill included $7 million for environmental justice programs at the Environmental Protection Agency and Department of the Interior, a $2 million increase from the previous year.
